title: Procter & Gamble descendants ask shareholders to shake up the board over deforestation
summary: Descendants of Procter & Gamble founders, who are also shareholders, are urging fellow shareholders to vote against four board nominees, including CEO Jon Moeller, due to the company's perceived insufficient efforts to combat deforestation. This campaign follows a 2020 shareholder vote where 67% called for P&G to escalate its efforts to eliminate deforestation from its supply chains. Investors like the New York Pension Fund and Green Century Capital Management have supported this move, highlighting the company's failure to adequately respond to environmental concerns.

title: P&G shareholders reject board changes sought by founding families; descendants say they're 'not going away'
summary: Procter & Gamble shareholders voted against proposals from descendants of the company's founders who sought more aggressive action against deforestation. Despite the rejection, the descendants and environmental advocates asserted their commitment to continue pressing P&G on its supply chain practices, noting a noticeable decrease in "yes" votes for some board members compared to the previous year. P&G stated its commitments to forestry are among the most rigorous in the industry and highlighted its partnerships with organizations like the Forest Stewardship Council.

title: Founding families press Procter & Gamble Co. to save the world’s forests
summary: Descendants of Procter & Gamble's founding families are urging the company to adopt stronger environmental policies, particularly concerning deforestation linked to its wood pulp and palm oil sourcing. About 100 P&G descendants have signed letters and engage in "inside out strategy" to pressure executives for change, despite the company's claims of sustainable sourcing. This generational quest aims to redefine P&G's environmental stewardship and address climate change.

title: P&G Earnings Show Its Pricing Power Endures
summary: Procter & Gamble continues to demonstrate strong pricing power as consumers accept higher prices for its premium brands like Tide, despite a slip in sales volumes. The company successfully raised prices by 7% in the June quarter, following two consecutive quarters of approximately 10% year-over-year increases. This strategy has helped prop up P&G's sales, indicating consumers' willingness to pay more for essential goods from the company.

title: Environmental protesters target P&G CEO's $2.8M house in Covington Tuesday
summary: Environmental protesters are targeting Procter & Gamble CEO Jon Moeller's Covington home with a mobile billboard to protest the company's forestry and sourcing policies ahead of its annual shareholder meeting. The protest is part of a broader push by activist investors, including conservative and progressive groups, who are presenting several measures to shareholders in opposition to the company's current practices. These measures include challenges against board members over forest destruction, demands for reports on the impact of diversity policies and dependence on China, and proposals regarding shareholder election rights.

title: P&G Bought Gillette 18 Years Ago. It’s Still Paying the Price.
summary: Procter & Gamble is taking a $1.3 billion accounting charge on its Gillette business, nearly two decades after acquiring the shaving giant for $54 billion in 2005. The unit has faced challenges from new market entrants offering lower-priced alternatives. As of June 2023, P&G estimated Gillette's grooming business to be worth approximately $14.1 billion.

title: 5 Reasons to Avoid Procter & Gamble Stock (PG) Without Hesitation
summary: This article outlines five reasons why investors may want to avoid buying Procter & Gamble stock (PG), despite its reputation as a safe consumer products company. The reasons include its expensive valuation at 24 times earnings, potential for slower earnings-per-share growth due to higher input prices, consumer shift to cheaper generic brands during a recession, a "good but not great" dividend yield of 2.59%, and alleged environmental issues related to sourcing. The article suggests holding existing shares but advises against new purchases.

title: Kellanova Paves Way to Less Plastic: A Glimpse Into Innovative Packaging
summary: Kellanova is making significant strides in reducing plastic waste by implementing innovative packaging solutions for its snack brands, resulting in a substantial reduction of plastic and corrugated cardboard. These efforts align with the company's "Kellanova Better Days Promise" to achieve 100% reusable, recyclable, or compostable packaging by 2030, emphasizing a circular economy approach and consumer education on recycling. The company's initiatives reflect a broader industry trend towards sustainable packaging, driven by environmental concerns and consumer demand.

title: P&G shares slump amid $2B+ in reported charges for restructuring, Gillette write down
summary: Procter & Gamble announced a $1 billion write down of Gillette's market value and restructuring moves on Dec. 5. This decision comes as the U.S. dollar continues to strengthen against other currencies, impacting P&G's shares. The write down contributes to over $2 billion in reported charges for the company.

title: P&G Will Take Up to $2.5 Billion in Charges for Restructuring, Gillette Impairment
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. announced charges of up to $2.5 billion over the next two fiscal years for restructuring operations in certain enterprise markets, including Argentina and Nigeria, and a non-cash impairment related to its Gillette business. The company's shares fell 3.5% following the announcement. P&G warned that while Gillette's performance is strong, future adverse conditions could lead to further impairment charges.

title: P&G to record up to $2.5 bln in Gillette writedown, operations rejig
summary: Procter & Gamble announced it would record up to $2.5 billion in charges over two fiscal years, including a $1.3 billion non-cash impairment charge on its Gillette business and $1 billion to $1.5 billion related to restructuring operations in Argentina and Nigeria. These charges are attributed to writing down the value of Gillette and difficult macroeconomic conditions compounded by a stronger dollar. The consumer goods giant expects these charges to be recognized in fiscal years 2024 and 2025, leading to a 2% drop in its shares.

title: P&G to Record Up to $2.5 Billion in Charges Related to Gillette Business, Restructuring
summary: Procter & Gamble announced it would record up to $2.5 billion in charges over two fiscal years. These charges are linked to writing down the value of its Gillette business, which it acquired in 2005, and restructuring efforts in certain markets like Argentina and Nigeria. The company attributed these charges, which include a $1.3 billion non-cash impairment charge on Gillette, partly to a stronger US dollar and difficult macroeconomic conditions.

title: Warren Buffett-Led Berkshire Hathaway Sells Its Entire Procter & Gamble Stake. Should You?
summary: Berkshire Hathaway fully exited its small position in Procter & Gamble, likely due to consolidating its portfolio and P&G's premium valuation compared to other opportunities like Apple. Despite Berkshire's sale, P&G is still considered a worthwhile investment for risk-averse individuals due to its strong brand development, pricing power, and commitment to shareholder returns through dividends and buybacks. The article suggests that while P&G's valuation is high, its other characteristics make it a solid choice for passive income and portfolio stability.

title: S&P turns negative on Clorox after cyberattack causes shortages
summary: S&P Global Ratings lowered its outlook for Clorox Co. to negative due to stock shortages and lost distribution following a cyberattack earlier this year. The attack led to widespread operational disruptions, switching to manual processes, and a significant 26% drop in sales volumes by September 30. While S&P affirmed Clorox's BBB+ rating, analysts expressed concerns about the lengthy recovery process and potential long-term impacts on shelf space and market share.

title: Household Cleaning Products Market to Reach US$ 355 Billion
summary: The global household cleaning products market is projected to reach US$ 355 billion by 2030, growing at an annual rate of over 4.8% from its 2023 valuation of US$ 255.7 billion. This growth is driven by increasing demand for effective hygiene and home care solutions, coupled with innovations in convenient and user-friendly products. Laundry detergents hold the largest market share, with the Asia Pacific region being dominant, influenced by factors like home improvement trends and rising disposable incomes.

title: ‘Effectiveness breeds spending’: Procter & Gamble moves to take more marketing in-house
summary: Procter & Gamble is continuing its strategy of taking more marketing functions in-house, shifting media planning duties for several brands from Dentsu's Carat to internal teams. This move aligns with CEO Jon Moeller's philosophy that greater marketing efficiency leads to more spending and drives market growth. P&G has already increased its marketing spend and plans further investment as it aims to return to pre-pandemic ad levels, focusing on digital reach and targeting improvements.

title: P&G: Stop Forest Destruction
summary: Rainforest Action Network (RAN) criticizes Procter & Gamble (P&G) for weakening its Forest Commodity Policy, which now permits forest degradation from industrial logging in its wood pulp supply chain. RAN is pressuring P&G to cease ties with Royal Golden Eagle (RGE) due to land grabs in Indigenous territories and to uphold Indigenous land rights by requiring Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC). The organization escalated its campaign, leading protests and actions culminating in a large rally and banner drop before P&G's Annual General Meeting to demand an end to forest destruction.

title: LPGA, ESPN Agree to New Two-Year Deal Through 2025
summary: The LPGA and ESPN have signed a new two-year agreement to stream Featured Group coverage at eight LPGA Tour events live and exclusively on ESPN+ through the 2025 season. This deal expands ESPN's commitment to golf and women's sports, offering fans more opportunities to watch LPGA athletes. The agreement includes coverage of this week’s CME Group Tour Championship and the 2024 CME Group Tour Championship.

title: Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Sells Out of GM, P&G, Johnson & Johnson, and Other Longtime Holdings
summary: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A, BRK.B) engaged in significant selling activity during the third quarter, offloading $5.7 billion in equities. Notable divestitures included entire stakes in GM, Johnson & Johnson, Procter & Gamble, and Activision Blizzard, alongside reductions in Chevron and HP. The company also acquired new positions primarily due to corporate actions by Liberty Media and continued investments in Japanese trading houses.

title: Procter & Gamble introduces innovative Pampers diaper with blowout protections
summary: Procter & Gamble has launched a new version of its Pampers Swaddlers diapers featuring a "Blowout Barrier," marking its most significant innovation for the brand since 2018. This product aims to provide enhanced protection against blowouts.

title: Procter & Gamble introduces 'blowout-proof' Pampers diaper - Bizwomen
summary: Procter & Gamble has launched a significant innovation in its Pampers Swaddlers line, introducing a "Blowout Barrier" designed to prevent up to 100% of leaks. This improvement, which is the biggest for the brand since 2018, aims to alleviate parents' fears about diaper blowouts, a common issue affecting millions of U.S. parents weekly. The company enlisted celebrity endorsements and highlighted survey data on the widespread impact of blowouts to market the new product.

title: Colgate-Palmolive raises prices again and says the consumer is ‘resilient’
summary: Colgate-Palmolive (COL) reported stronger-than-expected third-quarter earnings after raising prices by an average of 9.5% globally. This move, similar to Procter & Gamble (PG), helped boost profit margins by combating inflationary pressures. The company has repeatedly increased prices over the past year.

title: How Cincinnati public company CEOs rank by shareholder return
summary: An analysis by the Cincinnati Business Courier ranked Dr. August Troendle, CEO of Medpace Holdings, as the top-performing CEO among Greater Cincinnati public companies based on total shareholder return relative to the S&P 500 during his tenure. The article previews how other local public companies, including P&G and Kroger, performed in this ranking.

title: P&G's AI Factory Scaling Data Science Innovations
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) is heavily investing in artificial intelligence to scale its applications across various enterprise functions, from product innovation to back-office operations. The company's "AI Factory" has already proven to significantly increase the efficiency of its data scientists and has led to successful initiatives like Pampers MyPerfectFit. P&G aims to become an "AI-first" business by focusing on clear business purpose, building organizational AI fluency, and standardizing AI development.

title: Empowering Employee ‘P&G + Me’ Stories
summary: This article highlights several P&G employees who share their personal experiences and reasons for loving their careers at the company. It emphasizes P&G's commitment to employee growth, compassion, and fostering a supportive work environment. The testimonials showcase how P&G enables personal and professional development, values diverse voices, and connects employees' passions with their purpose.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Opens AI-Infused Plant to Propel Hill’s Growth
summary: Colgate-Palmolive has opened a new 365,000-square-foot AI-infused manufacturing plant in Tonganoxie, KS, for its Hill’s Pet Nutrition brand to overcome capacity constraints and drive growth. The advanced facility utilizes artificial intelligence, automation, and robotics, including automated guided vehicles and autonomous mobile robots, to enhance efficiency and food safety. This investment aims to boost Hill's Pet Nutrition's rapid growth, which has consistently been a strong performer for Colgate-Palmolive, and expand its presence in the wet pet food category.

title: Procter & Gamble Earnings: Sales and Margins Pop, but Competitive and Macro Headwinds Loom
summary: Procter & Gamble reported strong Q1 results with organic sales jumping 7% and gross margins surging, driven by higher prices and lower commodity costs. Morningstar expects to slightly increase its fair value estimate for P&G stock but notes that shares are not a bargain, advising investors to watch for a potential dip. Despite competitive and macro headwinds, P&G's strategic investments in R&D and marketing are expected to maintain its competitive edge.

title: Higher Prices Drive Procter & Gamble's Better-Than-Expected Earnings
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) reported stronger-than-expected Q1 FY 2024 earnings, with sales up 6% and profit up 17% year-over-year, primarily driven by higher product prices. While some segments saw declining sales volume due to these price increases, the overall financial performance remained robust. The company's successful management of prices and margins has been crucial in navigating inflation, leading to a significant increase in gross margin for the quarter.

title: Procter & Gamble, Cintas lead list of Cincinnati’s most valuable public companies by market capitalization
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. maintains its position as the largest Greater Cincinnati company by market capitalization. While Cintas Corp. ranks second, LSI Industries showed the most significant market cap growth among the region's 21 locally based public companies this year.

title: Procter & Gamble makes Forbes' World's Best Employers list for 2023
summary: Procter & Gamble, the Cincinnati-based consumer goods giant, has been named to Forbes' list of the world's best employers for 2023. It is the only local company from Cincinnati to achieve this recognition. The article highlights P&G's continuous prominence in business and employment rankings.

title: Clorox advances circular packaging, but virgin material reduction still a challenge
summary: Clorox made progress in its circular packaging goals, with 88% of its plastic packaging now reusable, recyclable, or compostable, partly by removing non-recyclable labels. However, the company is falling behind its virgin material reduction target, achieving only a 9% reduction toward a 50% goal by 2030. Extended producer responsibility policies could significantly increase costs for Clorox if national regulations are adopted.

title: Dividend Aristocrats may shine again if the Fed causes another bad year for the stock market
summary: The article suggests that Dividend Aristocrats, which performed well during the 2022 market downturn, could again be a strong investment if rising interest rates lead to another challenging year for the broader stock market. With investors becoming nervous due to increasing long-term rates, dividend stocks are presented as a potential safe haven. The piece indicates that the S&P Dividend Aristocrats, defined by S&P Dow Jones Indices, may warrant increased investor consideration.

title: Undervalued by 30%, This Wide-Moat Dividend Stock Is a Buy
summary: Morningstar identifies Campbell Soup (CPB) as an undervalued wide-moat dividend stock, projecting annual dividend increases at a mid-single-digit rate over the next decade. Despite near-term challenges like increasing competition and cost pressures, the company's strategic focus, brand intangible assets, and cost advantage support a long-term bullish outlook. Morningstar's fair value estimate is $61, suggesting the stock is currently undervalued by 30%.

title: Clorox Hack Opens Door For Competitors to Grab Market Share
summary: Clorox Co. is facing a significant risk of losing market share to competitors following a cybersecurity attack that disrupted its US factories and caused product shortages. While most factories have resumed production, some remain offline, leading to empty shelves and opportunities for rival brands to capture market share that may persist. This situation impacts various Clorox products, from bleach to cat litter, and is expected to bolster competing brands.

title: CMO 50 2023: Procter & Gamble’s long-term investments in sustainability reap rewards with younger generations
summary: Procter & Gamble's long-term focus on sustainability and environmental responsibility has helped it gain favor with younger generations, despite their skepticism towards large corporations. The company's marketing strategy integrates ESG principles into its core business, leading to authentic sustainability messages that resonate with consumers and address "big is bad" sentiments. This approach ensures P&G's brands are seen as not just promising, but actively delivering on their commitments to a more sustainable future.

title: The Price Of Procter & Gamble Company Is Simply Too High (NYSE:PG)
summary: The article argues that Procter & Gamble, despite its strong position as a consumer staple leader with consistent revenue, EPS growth, and a 67-year dividend increase streak, is currently overvalued. While it offers promising growth opportunities and shareholder commitment, its high valuation leaves no margin of safety, especially in uncertain economic conditions. The author, a dividend growth investor, is seeking new investment opportunities but finds PG's current price unattractive.

title: Better Stock Buy: Coca-Cola vs. Procter & Gamble
summary: This article compares Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble, two major consumer staples companies, to determine which is a better stock buy. It highlights their similarities in business resilience and dividend history, while scrutinizing their differences in product offerings and, critically, their current valuations based on price-to-sales, price-to-earnings, and price-to-book ratios. The analysis concludes that Coca-Cola appears more attractively priced historically compared to P&G.

title: Active Ingredient in Hundreds of Cold and Flu Meds Is ‘Entirely Ineffective,’ Class Action Says
summary: A class action lawsuit has been filed against fourteen companies for selling over-the-counter cold and flu medicines containing phenylephrine, an active ingredient that an FDA advisory panel deemed "entirely ineffective" at treating nasal congestion. The lawsuit claims that these companies, including makers of popular brands like Tylenol and Sudafed, have long marketed their products as effective despite knowing the ingredient works no better than a placebo. This legal action follows a unanimous FDA advisory committee vote that phenylephrine does not work to treat nasal congestion, raising questions about its continued use in numerous products.

title: Shareholding descendants of P&G founders blast company leadership on forest degradation policy
summary: Descendants of Procter & Gamble's founders, who are also shareholders, have publicly criticized the company's leadership for removing pledges against forest degradation in its supply chain. These nine shareholders contend that P&G's current policies expose it to significant financial and regulatory risks, prompting calls for leadership changes within the company.

title: Dishwashing Products Market Size, Growth Trends, Forecasts,
summary: The global dishwashing products market is projected to reach over US$ 30.8 billion by 2030, growing at an annual rate of 5.8% from its 2022 valuation of US$ 19.6 billion. The report by RationalStat highlights the importance of these products for hygiene, their diverse formats, and the growing demand driven by convenience, particularly for automatic dishwasher detergents. North America is expected to dominate the market regionally, while the liquid segment is forecast to hold the largest share by type.

title: P&G enlists IoT, predictive analytics to perfect Pampers diapers
summary: Procter & Gamble is leveraging IoT and predictive analytics, specifically Microsoft's IoT and edge analytics platform, to enhance the production of Pampers diapers. This initiative, dubbed Hot Melt Optimization, uses proprietary sensors and machine learning to predict and prevent manufacturing failures, significantly reducing waste and improving efficiency. The system has eliminated 70% of flawed diapers in 11 plants, showcasing the impact of data-driven innovation in manufacturing.

title: Top Analyst Reports for Procter & Gamble, AbbVie & Walt Disney
summary: This article summarizes top analyst reports from Zacks Research Daily on Procter & Gamble (PG), AbbVie (ABBV), and The Walt Disney Company (DIS). It details the financial performance, challenges, and growth prospects for each company, highlighting key drivers and headwinds. Additionally, it mentions other noteworthy reports on HSBC, Boston Scientific, and Duke Energy.

title: Colgate-Palmolive and P&G lag behind Unilever at cutting back emissions
summary: A new study by Planet Tracker indicates that Unilever is outperforming Colgate-Palmolive and Procter & Gamble (P&G) in achieving climate transition goals, with the latter companies' projected emissions to 2030 being seven times higher than recommended levels. The report emphasizes the significant financial risks associated with continued high emissions for these FMCG companies, particularly concerning Scope 3 emissions. While Unilever has a more comprehensive mitigation strategy and includes downstream Scope 3 emissions in its targets, all companies still face challenges in meeting stricter climate objectives.

title: With 66% ownership of the shares, The Procter & Gamble Company (NYSE:PG) is heavily dominated by institutional owners
summary: Institutional investors hold a significant 66% ownership in The Procter & Gamble Company (NYSE:PG), making them the dominant shareholder group and influencing the company's stock price and board decisions. The two largest institutional shareholders are The Vanguard Group, Inc. and BlackRock, Inc. Retail investors, through the general public, own 34% of the company's shares.

title: Detergent Market Size to Grow by $31.5 Billion from 2022 to 2027: Technavio
summary: The global detergent market is projected to grow by $31.5 billion between 2022 and 2027, driven by factors such as the increasing generation of industrial waste and product innovation. North America, with Procter and Gamble dominating, is expected to contribute significantly to this growth. Emerging trends include new packaging designs focusing on flexibility and sustainability, while high price wars pose a significant challenge to market expansion.
source: Happi | Household And Personal Products Industry
source_domain: Happi | Household And Personal Products Industry

title: Procter & Gamble Executive Joins Barton School Dean’s Advisory Board
summary: Tadd Fowler, Senior Vice President, Treasurer and Global Taxes at The Procter & Gamble Company, has joined the Barton School Dean’s Advisory Board at Wichita State University. An alumnus of the Barton School, Fowler brings extensive expertise in global treasury and tax matters from his role at P&G, where he manages over $10 billion in annual global tax contributions. This addition is expected to significantly enhance the student experience and curriculum innovation at the Barton School of Business.

title: Procter & Gamble Earnings: Margins Rebuild Even as Investments Persist
summary: Procter & Gamble's fourth-quarter earnings showed significant gross margin expansion to 48.4%, driven by higher prices and productivity savings. The company continues to invest in R&D and marketing, supporting its wide economic moat. While Morningstar expects to slightly raise its fair value estimate of P&G stock, shares are currently considered unattractive, trading at a premium to their intrinsic valuation.

title: P&G Trimming SKUs As Part of Collaborative Commerce Strategy
summary: Procter & Gamble is reducing its SKU count, leveraging POS data and proprietary algorithms to optimize product offerings and improve service levels. This initiative is part of a larger collaborative commerce strategy with retail partners, aiming to drive efficiencies, productivity, and maximize overall sales throughput, as other CPG companies like Mondelez and Unilever have also done. The company views SKU rationalization as both a cost-saving and top-line growth opportunity, enhancing its evolving omnichannel strategy.

title: Will inflation make consumers abandon their favorite brands?
summary: Procter & Gamble is being cautious about its 2024 outlook despite better-than-expected quarterly earnings, driven by concerns that inflation may cause consumers to abandon their favorite brands for cheaper alternatives. While brand loyalty is strong due to habit, P&G mitigates this risk by offering a range of brands at different price points, allowing consumers to trade down within its own product portfolio.

title: P&G Beats Profit and Sales Estimates on Higher Prices
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) surpassed profit and sales estimates for its fiscal 2023 fourth quarter, driven by higher prices for its products, even while facing increased costs. Shares rose over 3% following the announcement. However, the company's outlook for fiscal 2024 fell below forecasts due to anticipated macroeconomic challenges.

title: P&G’s Vanished Forest Degradation Commitment
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has removed its commitment to prohibit forest degradation from its latest forest sourcing policy, despite previous investor pressure. This move suggests a backtracking on responsible sourcing claims, leaving P&G as a continued driver of degradation in Canada's boreal forests, which has significant climate and biodiversity impacts. The NRDC highlights that P&G's previous claims were misleading and calls for a genuine commitment to eliminate forest degradation.

title: Better Buy: Procter & Gamble vs. Clorox
summary: This article compares Procter & Gamble (PG) and Clorox (CLX), concluding that P&G is the better buy primarily due to its significantly larger marketing budget and ability to dominate competitive markets. While Clorox leads in niche categories, P&G's financial muscle allows it to consistently out-promote competitors and maintain an "unfair advantage" in consumer staples. The article emphasizes that P&G's size allows it to better navigate consumer price sensitivity and market competition.

title: Procter & Gamble's Jeff Kent Discusses AI and Machine Learning
summary: Jeff Kent, VP of Smart Platforms Technology & Innovation at Procter & Gamble, detailed the company's application of AI and machine learning to cut manufacturing costs and improve operations. P&G aims for significant efficiency gains and cost reductions using its "WISE" initiative, including the SmartBox edge device, and is implementing thousands of machine learning algorithms across its global sites. The company is strategically moving beyond the traditional Purdue model to achieve more direct and agnostic communication in its push for digitalization and Industry 4.0.

title: A Discussion With P&G's Chief Sustainability Officer
summary: This article features an interview with Virginie Helias, P&G's Chief Sustainability Officer, discussing the evolution of sustainability at P&G and their strategies to tackle the plastic waste crisis. Helias highlights P&G's shift from regulatory compliance to embedding sustainability across all business functions and emphasizes the importance of partnerships and collaboration to achieve circularity goals, particularly in developing markets. She details P&G's progress towards reducing virgin plastic and increasing recyclable packaging, and outlines their efforts to create a more sustainable and equitable plastics value chain through responsible sourcing and community engagement.

title: 2022’s Top Advertisers: P&G, Comcast Join Radio’s $200 Million Club.
summary: Procter & Gamble and Comcast Corp. both surpassed $200 million in radio ad spending in 2022, securing their positions as top advertisers. P&G increased its radio allocation by 48% and Comcast by 35%, while other significant spenders included Deutsche Telekom, the U.S. Government, Berkshire Hathaway, and Pfizer, with Pfizer showing the fastest growth among major advertisers. The article also highlights shifts in ad spending across different media, with AVOD and local radio seeing significant increases.

title: Colgate-Palmolive beats Q4 profit estimates helped by price hikes
summary: Colgate-Palmolive (India) Ltd's fourth-quarter profit fell less than expected, helped by price hikes implemented to combat surging costs. The company reported a 2.3% fall in net profit to 3.16 billion rupees, while sales rose nearly 4% to 13.42 billion rupees due to price increases. Its better-than-feared earnings follow previous drops in profit and come as other consumer goods makers also report mixed earnings for the March quarter.

title: India's P&G Hygiene and Health Care posts drop in Q3 sales on muted demand
summary: Procter & Gamble Hygiene and Health Care Ltd (PROC.NS) reported a 1% dip in Q3 sales to 8.81 billion rupees ($107.73 million) due to waning pandemic-driven demand for healthcare products and elevated inflation. Despite the sales drop, the company's profit rose to 1.65 billion rupees, benefiting from a 575 million rupees gain from tax adjustments. The company's shares have fallen about 6% this year, amidst a challenging operating environment.

title: How Procter & Gamble supports employees’ dual role as caregivers
summary: Procter & Gamble has implemented a two-pronged approach to support its employees in their caregiving roles, recognizing that caregiving extends beyond just childcare to include a wide range of family and non-family members. Following an employee focus group, P&G hired a concierge service, Cariloop, to help employees find resources and financial aid for caregiving, and also developed strategies to help managers and teams discuss caregiving issues openly. This initiative aims to reduce employee stress, increase productivity, and aid in retaining diverse talent, although some employees still face skepticism or guilt regarding the use of such services.

title: Bleach maker Clorox raises annual forecasts on higher prices
summary: Clorox Co. raised its annual sales and profit forecasts due to higher product prices, which helped the company overcome a slowdown in demand. Despite a drop in volume for some segments, price hikes increased gross margins and led to a 6% rise in net sales for the third quarter. The company now expects fiscal 2023 net sales to increase between 1% to 2% and projects annual adjusted earnings between $4.35 and $4.50 per share.

title: Colgate-Palmolive’s stock pops after earnings beat as company raises prices by double-digit percentage
summary: Colgate-Palmolive's stock rose 3.6% after reporting better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, driven by significant price increases, including a 10.5% hike in North America. This trend reflects the pricing power demonstrated by several consumer-goods companies this earnings season, such as Procter & Gamble, Kimberly-Clark, PepsiCo, Nestlé, and Unilever, who also implemented double-digit price increases with minimal impact on sales volumes.

title: The latest innovations to help people be well and thrive
summary: The Clorox Company highlights recent innovations across its brands, focusing on products designed to meet consumer needs and support well-being. These innovations include Clorox Free & Clear cleaning products, Fresh Step Crystals Health Monitoring Litter, and new portable collagen and magnesium supplements. The article also showcases sustainable packaging from Burt's Bees and new flavor offerings from Hidden Valley Ranch and more durable Glad trash bags.

title: Kimberly-Clark lifts 2023 profit forecast on higher prices
summary: Kimberly-Clark Corp raised its full-year profit forecast for 2023, driven by consistent price hikes that led to better-than-expected first-quarter sales despite weak volumes. The company's gross margin increased to 33.2% as it raised prices across all categories by 10%, mirroring a trend seen with peer Procter & Gamble, which also benefited from price increases. Kimberly-Clark now expects 2023 profit growth between 6% and 10%.

title: Kimberly-Clark CEO again promises big developments in the ‘poop’ category
summary: Kimberly-Clark's stock jumped after the company reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings and raised its full-year guidance. The company, known for Kleenex, Huggies, and Cottonelle, announced a 10% price increase for the second consecutive quarter, significantly expanding gross margins. The CEO also hinted at exciting upcoming innovations in bathroom tissue, referring to it as "a better clean" in the "poop" category.

title: P&G expects $2.2B hit from supply costs in 2023
summary: Procter & Gamble anticipates a $2.2 billion hit to earnings in 2023 due to inflation in commodity and material costs, despite price hikes and productivity savings. The company is leveraging its "Supply Chain 3.0" initiative and digital investments to achieve $1.5 billion in savings and enhance its competitive advantage against rising costs and private label brands. While price increases have significantly boosted gross margins, P&G faces growing retailer resistance to further hikes, leading it to focus on improving its offerings and sustained investment in innovation.

title: Margin care: Consumer giant Procter & Gamble is navigating inflation with ease
summary: Procter & Gamble reported strong quarterly earnings and revenue growth, exceeding Wall Street expectations and raising its 2023 outlook, despite accusations of "greedflation" due to price hikes. The consumer goods giant, with over 65 brands, demonstrated healthy profit margins across its diverse divisions, particularly in Fabric & Home Care, Grooming, and Beauty. Sales volume decreased, but a 10% average price increase resulted in a 4% overall sales rise.

title: Procter & Gamble rakes in profits after 10% price hike amid inflation
summary: Procter & Gamble reported strong quarterly sales and profits, driven by a 10% price hike across its brands, particularly in fabric and home care. Despite inflation-weary consumers buying fewer products, the company exceeded Wall Street expectations for sales and earnings and raised its outlook for fiscal 2023. Sales volume declines were moderated by the economic reopening in China, P&G's second-biggest market.

title: P&G Says Consumer Demand Is Stabilising Despite Higher Prices
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. raised its sales projection for the fiscal year ending in June, citing higher prices and a slight increase in demand for some products, with shares rising the most in three years. Despite a decline in total unit sales, the company noted that volumes are starting to stabilise, particularly in the US, and that while some costs are easing, bottom-line forecasts remain cautious due to ongoing high labour and commodity costs. The gains were primarily driven by a 10 percent jump in prices, with specific volume increases seen in beauty and healthcare segments, offsetting declines in other divisions.

title: Double-Digit Price Increases Bolster Profits at Procter & Gamble (Published 2023)
summary: Procter & Gamble reported bolstered profits in the first quarter of 2023 due to a 10 percent price increase across its brands, marking the second consecutive quarter of double-digit hikes. This strategy allowed the company's profit margin to expand, offsetting increased raw material costs, even as sales volumes declined slightly. P&G also raised its revenue forecast for the fiscal year and announced plans for a significant stock buyback program.

title: Procter & Gamble's earnings boosted by higher prices for Pampers diapers and Bounty kitchen paper
summary: Procter & Gamble's fiscal third-quarter earnings exceeded Wall Street expectations due to price increases on household products like Tide, Bounty, and Pampers. The company raised prices by approximately 10% across its brands, indicating that consumers are not switching to cheaper private-label alternatives. This led to a 3.5% rise in P&G's stock on Friday.

title: P&G Unwinds ‘Precision’ Makeup Brand Opte Four Years After Launch
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. is phasing out its "precision" makeup brand Opte, an inkjet wand for targeted makeup application, four years after its launch. The decision was made as part of P&G Ventures' strategy to focus on products with the biggest impact, despite Opte being touted for several years and receiving an innovation award. P&G will continue to offer technical and warranty support though new product and refill orders have ceased.

title: Top 10 Procter & Gamble Competitors & Alternatives
summary: This article lists the top 10 competitors and alternatives to Procter & Gamble, a leading consumer goods company. It provides details on each competitor, including their founding year, headquarters, key products, and historical background. The list highlights the diverse range of companies vying for market share in the consumer goods sector against P&G.

title: P&G CEO Jon Moeller ’86: ‘Constructive disruption’ creates value
summary: P&G CEO Jon Moeller ’86 discussed how "constructive disruption" through organizational restructuring and portfolio changes significantly boosted the company's organic sales. Moeller emphasized focusing on daily use categories where performance drives brand choice and creating financial flexibility for strategic investments. He also shared his leadership philosophy, highlighting the importance of energizing and enabling employees and fostering intellectual curiosity.

title: Attackers start leaking Procter & Gamble data
summary: Russia-linked ransomware syndicate Cl0p has begun leaking what they claim is commercial data belonging to Procter & Gamble (P&G). This leak stems from a vulnerability in Fortra's GoAnywhere managed file transfer software, which Cl0p has exploited to breach numerous companies. P&G confirmed that one of its entities was affected but maintains that no sensitive customer data like Social Security numbers or credit card details were exposed, with the leaked samples primarily showing commercial client purchase information.

title: Procter & Gamble confirm breach
summary: Procter & Gamble confirmed that one of its companies was affected by the Fortra GoAnywhere vulnerability, leading to a breach where attackers obtained some employee information. The company stated that no sensitive data like social security numbers, credit card details, or customer data was compromised, and business operations continue normally. The Russia-linked Cl0p ransomware syndicate, which claimed responsibility, has victimized numerous organizations using this zero-day flaw.

title: Cyber thieves swipe worker information at Cincinnati-based Procter and Gamble
summary: Cyber thieves have stolen worker information from Cincinnati-based Procter and Gamble by exploiting a bug in an external file transfer tool called GoAnywhere. P&G confirmed that personal data of employees was compromised, but stated that sensitive information like social security numbers or banking details were not included, and no customer data was taken. A cybersecurity expert noted that a Russian group selling "ransomware as a service" was likely responsible for the attack, highlighting the difficulty of maintaining 100% security against sophisticated threats.

title: Time For Procter & Gamble (Or A CPG) To Buy The Honest Company (NASDAQ:HNST)
summary: The article suggests that The Honest Company (HNST) should be acquired by a larger Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) company like Procter & Gamble due to its recent poor financial performance and a perceived lack of urgency from management. The author highlights the company's missed Q4 FY 2022 Adj. EBITDA and awful FY 2023 guidance as reasons for this recommendation, aiming to benefit long-suffering shareholders.

title: How Procter & Gamble is re-investing in radio to find TV audiences
summary: Procter & Gamble increased its radio spending by 43% last year to $235 million as a strategy to reach TV audiences. This reinvestment highlights a media spending shift to find consumers through different channels.

title: Should You Buy This Households & Personal Products Company Over Colgate-Palmolive Stock?
summary: This article analyzes whether Procter & Gamble (P&G) or Colgate-Palmolive (CL) is a better investment in the consumer-defensive sector. While both stocks are compared on revenue growth, profitability, and financial position, P&G is deemed the better choice due to superior metrics, despite trading at a higher valuation. The analysis suggests P&G stock will offer better returns than CL stock in the next three years.

title: Navigate 2023 With Recession-Resistant ETF ZECP
summary: The Zacks Earnings Consistent Portfolio ETF (ZECP) is presented as a recession-resistant strategy for investors concerned about a potential economic downturn in 2023. ZECP, Zacks Investment Management's first ETF, identifies companies with strong balance sheets and consistent earnings, having demonstrated resilience through past recessions. The fund seeks to offer an active approach to navigate market volatility, focusing on quality companies with stable historic and forecasted earnings per share.

title: BlackRock — the world’s largest asset manager — says central banks are 'deliberately' causing recessions and warns of a downturn unlike any other. 3 shockproof assets for your protection
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, predicts a unique recession caused by central banks deliberately overtightening policy to combat inflation, warning that central banks may not intervene to rescue the economy. The firm suggests investors consider "shockproof" assets like consumer staples, fine wine, and real estate as hedges against this impending downturn.

title: Procter & Gamble CIO: ‘Everybody Must Own the Digital Story’
summary: Procter & Gamble CIO Vittorio Cretella emphasizes the importance of digital transformation across the entire CPG ecosystem to improve customer experiences, build loyalty, and drive growth. He details how P&G leverages technologies like AI, IoT, and cloud computing for everything from product formulation and manufacturing efficiency to consumer engagement and privacy. Cretella also addresses challenges in scaling AI, highlighting the need for integrating data, developing talent, and fostering a culture that embraces automation while prioritizing consumer trust and data privacy.

title: Former Clorox executive joins IFF board
summary: Dawn Willoughby, former executive vice president and chief operating officer of The Clorox Co., has been appointed as an independent director to the board of IFF, effective Feb. 1. Willoughby previously held roles at Procter & Gamble and currently serves on the boards of The J.M. Smucker Co. and TE Connectivity. IFF's chair, Dale Morrison, highlighted Willoughby's relevant skills and experience in supporting the company's growth and transformation.

title: Procter & Gamble Earnings Show Resiliency but Stock Overvalued
summary: Procter & Gamble's fiscal second-quarter 2023 earnings report indicates the company is successfully navigating macroeconomic and competitive challenges, with results largely meeting market expectations. Despite this resiliency and an increase in organic sales growth guidance, Morningstar analysts consider the stock overvalued at its current price compared to their fair value estimate. Investors are advised to await a more attractive entry point, even as P&G demonstrates strength in consumer loyalty amid price increases.

title: Corium Pharma Solutions Appoints Mark Sirgo as Chief Executive Officer
summary: Corium Pharma Solutions has appointed Dr. Mark Sirgo as its new Chief Executive Officer and a member of its Board of Directors. Dr. Sirgo brings over 35 years of pharmaceutical industry experience, including founding BioDelivery Sciences International and overseeing the development and commercialization of three products. His appointment is expected to drive the company's next phase of growth in transdermal contract development and manufacturing.

title: Hasbro toy company taps Chris Cocks as CEO
summary: Hasbro has appointed Chris Cocks, head of its digital gaming division and Wizards of the Coast, as its new CEO, effective February 25. He succeeds interim CEO Rich Stoddart, who will become board chairman. Under Cocks's leadership, Wizards of the Coast's revenue more than doubled, surpassing $1 billion in 2021.

title: Procter & Gamble continues sponsoring Russia’s war with two giant factories
summary: Procter & Gamble continues to operate two large factories in Russia, contributing significantly to the Russian budget through taxes and facilitating employee mobilization for military service, despite international condemnation of Russia's actions in Ukraine. This business activity contradicts P&G's stated ethical policies and supports the Russian economy, which in turn funds the invasion of Ukraine. The article highlights how P&G and other companies' continued presence in Russia undermines efforts to isolate the aggressor state and details the financial contributions made by P&G's operations in Russia.

title: Newell nabs new CFO, shuffles C-suite
summary: Newell Brands announced that Mark Erceg will become its new CFO, succeeding Chris Peterson, who will transition to president. Erceg, a Procter & Gamble alum, brings extensive financial experience from previous CFO roles at several major companies. This leadership change comes as Newell Brands faces slumping sales and economic uncertainty, with the company focused on aligning its cost structure.

title: P&G Doubles Down on Digital Capacity and Shelf Orchestration With Supply Chain 3.0
summary: Procter & Gamble is heavily investing in its Supply Chain 3.0 strategy, leveraging emerging technologies and advanced algorithms to drive productivity, cost effectiveness, and market growth. This digital transformation includes partnerships with companies like Microsoft for a digital platform utilizing IoT, AI, machine learning, and edge computing to enhance visibility and real-time decision-making across its manufacturing sites globally. P&G is also applying these advancements to optimize shelf orchestration based on point-of-sale data and shopper behavior, aiming to improve on-shelf availability and the overall shopping experience.

title: Teamsters Protest at Procter & Gamble Headquarters, Call on Company to Demand Supplier Monosol End Forced Labor
summary: Members of Teamsters Local 135 protested outside Procter & Gamble (P&G) headquarters, urging the company to compel its supplier MonoSol to cease forced overtime for workers and negotiate a fair contract. MonoSol, which supplies water-soluble packaging to P&G, recently locked out nearly 200 Teamsters after they rejected a contract offer and authorized a strike. The Teamsters are highlighting P&G's Responsible Sourcing Policy and MonoSol's commitment to the UN Global Compact, both of which prohibit forced labor and uphold workers' rights.

title: The 2022 Beauty Inc Awards: Retailers of the Year
summary: The 2022 Beauty Inc Awards recognized Walmart as Retailer of the Year for Mass and Ulta Beauty as Retailer of the Year for Specialty. Walmart was lauded for its strategic initiatives, including a partnership with Space NK and new brand launches targeting Gen Z. Ulta Beauty continued its strong growth, driven by its appeal to Gen Z consumers and successful launch of popular beauty brands.

title: Doing the Right Thing: A Business Built on Trust
summary: P&G employees celebrate their heritage and commitment to their Purpose, Values, and Principles (PVPs) during their annual "Do the Right Thing Celebration." This tradition dates back to 1887, when the company gained a reputation for quality products and ethical practices. The PVPs serve as the foundation for P&G's culture, guiding daily decisions and ensuring the company's enduring values are passed down through generations.

title: Environmentalists ask SEC to examine P&G's wood pulp supply chain claims
summary: An international environment advocacy group, the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), has asked the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to investigate Procter & Gamble Co.'s claims about its wood pulp supply chain. The NRDC alleges that P&G's statements regarding forest preservation are misleading to investors, as the company sources from pristine forests and caribou habitats to produce products like Charmin and Bounty. The group is pushing for SEC enforcement action or updated statements from P&G, citing concerns about investor perceptions and the company's reliance on third-party certifications.

title: P&G’s Forest Degradation Claim Warrants SEC Scrutiny
summary: The NRDC has filed a complaint with the SEC regarding Procter & Gamble's claims about forest degradation in its supply chains, arguing that P&G's statements are misleading to investors. Despite a 2020 shareholder vote urging P&G to address deforestation, the company's disclosures indicate continued sourcing from primary forests and reliance on inadequate third-party certifications. The NRDC recommends the SEC investigate these claims, require corrections, and consider enforcement action to protect investors and uphold sustainability standards.

title: Kimberly-Clark Corp. stock falls Tuesday, still outperforms market
summary: Kimberly-Clark Corp. (KMB) stock fell 0.11% on Tuesday, closing at $133.16, marking its second consecutive day of losses. Despite the decline, the stock still outperformed the broader market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising slightly and the S&P 500 Index falling. Kimberly-Clark also outperformed competitors Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble Co., which saw larger percentage drops.

title: Church & Dwight Co. stock rises Wednesday, outperforms market
summary: Church & Dwight Co. (CHD) stock increased by 0.61% to $78.57 on Wednesday, outperforming the broader market indexes like the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average. This marked the stock's fourth consecutive day of gains, although it remained below its 52-week high. The company's performance was mixed when compared to competitors like Johnson & Johnson, Procter & Gamble Co., and Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC.

title: Innovation Series: Behind P&G’s Bounty
summary: This article details the innovation behind Procter & Gamble's Bounty paper towels, focusing on Senior Inventor Paul Trokhan. Trokhan developed a secret technology in 1982 that gave Bounty its superior absorbency, strength, and softness, and his work resulted in nearly 250 patents. He retired in 2022, 40 years after his key Bounty invention, and believes the technology will continue to be successful for many more years.

title: Worker crushed to death by 3,000-pound container, NC officials say. Now company cited
summary: Procter & Gamble is facing a $34,000 fine for "serious" safety violations after a 49-year-old worker, Montrell Rudd, was crushed to death by a 3,000-pound container in their Browns Summit facility. The North Carolina Department of Labor cited the manufacturer for three violations, including failing to secure the container and operating the lift truck unsafely. P&G has requested an informal conference regarding the citations.

title: P&G Holds 2022 Investor Day
summary: P&G held its 2022 Investor Day on November 17, where executives reviewed the company's integrated business strategy and its strengthening through four focus areas. Chairman, President, and CEO Jon Moeller outlined how strategic choices drive balanced growth and value creation, focusing on a robust portfolio, superiority in products, productivity, constructive disruption, and an efficient organizational structure. The company also announced four areas of increased intentionality: supply chain excellence, environmental sustainability, digital acumen, and a superior employee value equation.

title: The Tom Ford acquisition is all about fragrance
summary: The article details Estée Lauder's acquisition of Tom Ford for $2.3 billion, highlighting that the primary driver for the deal is Tom Ford's highly successful fragrance business, which makes up a significant portion of its beauty sales. Estée Lauder plans to outsource Tom Ford's fashion and accessories lines while focusing on expanding the beauty segment, particularly in emerging markets like China and the Middle East, despite recent sales dips in Asia for Estée Lauder. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to secure a fast-growing brand and save on royalties.

title: [Latest] Global Mosquito Repellent Market Size/Share Worth USD 10.3 Billion by 2030 at a 7% CAGR: Custom Market Insights (Analysis, Outlook, Leaders, Report, Trends, Forecast, Segmentation, Growth, Growth Rate, Value, Analysis, Outlook)
summary: The global mosquito repellent market is projected to reach USD 10.3 billion by 2030, growing at a CAGR of 7% from its 2021 valuation of USD 5.1 billion. This growth is driven by increased urbanization, e-commerce adoption, rising awareness of natural products, and outdoor activities. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to dominate the market due to its large population, increasing disposable income, and government initiatives against mosquito-borne diseases.

title: Arizona city gives green light to Procter & Gamble manufacturing plant
summary: The city of Coolidge, Arizona, has approved an initial development agreement for Procter & Gamble's new 2 million-square-foot manufacturing plant. This decision follows an extensive search by P&G across 500 sites in multiple states. The facility is expected to be a significant addition to the area's industrial landscape.

title: Procter & Gamble picks site to build $500 million manufacturing facility
summary: Procter & Gamble plans to invest $500 million in a new fabric care manufacturing plant in Coolidge, Arizona, spanning over 400 acres. The 2 million square-foot facility will be located within the Inland Port Arizona industrial park and will support P&G's fabric care portfolio, including products like Tide Pods and Downy Unstopables. This investment aims to expand the company's manufacturing capabilities in the region.

title: Procter & Gamble unveils plans for $500 million manufacturing facility in Arizona
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. (PG) has announced plans to construct a new $500 million manufacturing facility in Arizona. This development was reported by the Cincinnati Business Courier and the Phoenix Business Journal. The Cincinnati-based consumer goods giant is making a significant investment in expanding its manufacturing capabilities.

title: Arizona Commerce Authority Announces New Procter & Gamble Manufacturing Facility To Be Built In Coolidge
summary: The Arizona Commerce Authority announced that Procter & Gamble (P&G) plans to build a new manufacturing facility in Coolidge, Arizona. This new facility, representing a $500 million investment and expected to be operational by 2025, will create approximately 500 new jobs and support P&G’s fabric care portfolio. Pinal County's strategic location and growing manufacturing ecosystem were cited as key factors in P&G's decision.

title: Procter & Gamble unveils plans for $500 million manufacturing facility in Arizona
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. (PG) plans to invest $500 million in building a new manufacturing facility in Arizona. The plant will be located on more than 400 acres, approximately an hour from Phoenix. This move comes after a year-long search for a suitable site for the consumer goods giant.

title: Eastman to provide PepsiCo with recycled PET
summary: Eastman has secured an offtake agreement with PepsiCo to supply processed PET from its third planned chemical recycling facility in the U.S. This facility, expected to be operational by the end of 2026, will have an input capacity of 160,000 tonnes/year of hard-to-recycle PET waste. The agreement is a significant step for Eastman's circular economy initiatives, with other similar facilities in Tennessee and France also underway.

title: P&G to offset rising costs with price increases, productivity initiatives
summary: Procter & Gamble plans to counter rising freight and commodity costs with price increases and new productivity initiatives. The company has already implemented a second round of price hikes and is focusing on optimizing its supply chain through its "Supply Chain 3.0" initiative, which will likely involve enhanced automation and digital capabilities. P&G expects a $3.9 billion after-tax headwind from commodities and logistics in fiscal year 2023.

title: Popular Dry Shampoos Found to Have Cancer-CausinTg Chemical
summary: An independent study by Valisure found that 70% of 148 batches from 34 brands of spray-on dry shampoo contained high levels of benzene, a known carcinogen. Brands like Not Your Mother's, Batiste, Sun Bum, and John Paul Mitchell Systems were identified, some with significantly higher benzene levels than previously found in other personal-care products. Valisure has filed a petition with the FDA requesting a recall of these products, highlighting concerns about the complexity of the supply chain and the regulation of cosmetics.

title: Flows Into Consumer Staples ETFs Rebound on Economic Uncertainty
summary: Investors are increasingly moving back into consumer staples ETFs, a defensive strategy during economic uncertainty. The Invesco S&P 500® Equal Weight Consumer Staples ETF (RHS) has seen significant net inflows, indicating a preference for equal-weighted approaches to mitigate company-specific risks that are common in market-cap weighted funds dominated by a few large companies. This shift reflects advisors' search for downside protection while still participating in market upside in the current economic climate.

title: A Road Less Traveled
summary: This article details the inspiring journey of Raymond Lynch, a P&G Global Ambassador for Employees with Disabilities and Medical Conditions. After a life-altering accident, Raymond advocated for greater disability inclusion within P&G, leading to the creation of support groups and training programs for employees with disabilities. His efforts have significantly advanced P&G's commitment to fostering a disability-confident culture and ensuring accessibility for all employees.

title: Milliken, PureCycle launch concentrate made with recycled PP resin
summary: Milliken & Co. and PureCycle Technologies have partnered to create the first fully sustainable concentrate for polypropylene (PP) made with recycled resin, offering a carbon footprint approximately 35 percent lower than virgin PP. This odorless, color-free concentrate expands the use of 100 percent recycled content in injection-molded parts and utilizes Milliken's Millad NX 8000 ECO clarifier for certified energy savings. PureCycle's CEO Dustin Olson highlights the concentrate's advantage of not requiring operational adjustments for customers, unlike other recycled materials.

title: Procter & Gamble trims ad spending again, but still beats forecasts
summary: Procter & Gamble has once again reduced its ad spending but still managed to surpass its financial forecasts. This indicates a continued trend for the consumer goods giant to optimize its advertising expenditures while maintaining strong business performance.

title: Procter & Gamble (PG) Stock Gains 2% on Earnings Beat
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) stock saw a 2% gain on Wednesday following an earnings beat for its fiscal first quarter, surpassing analyst expectations for both earnings and sales. Despite the positive financial results driven by price increases, the company issued a guidance downgrade for its fiscal year earnings due to currency effects and higher material costs, raising concerns about longer-term pricing sustainability and consumer affordability. The article highlights that while price hikes have helped mitigate expenses, they are also leading to a decline in sales volume and potential challenges as consumers tighten budgets.

title: Consumer Giants Keep Raising Prices as Profits Come Under Pressure (Published 2022)
summary: Nestlé and Procter & Gamble continued to raise prices last quarter, generating higher sales despite lower sales volumes as consumers face inflation. Both companies expect price increases to continue to offset rising costs and restore profit margins. This trend highlights how consumer giants are navigating inflation, impacting shoppers and posing a challenge for central banks.

title: The Price of Procter & Gamble’s Inaction
summary: Rainforest Action Network (RAN) protested Procter & Gamble's inaction on deforestation and human rights abuses in its supply chain, joined by descendants of P&G's founders and supported by major institutional investors. The article details P&G's continued sourcing from problematic suppliers linked to land grabs and illegal deforestation, despite shareholder pressure and internal commitments. It highlights the environmental harm and human suffering caused by P&G's pulp and palm oil sourcing, especially in Indonesia and the Canadian boreal.

title: P&G CEO and chairman, corporate directors re-elected to board after challenge
summary: Procter & Gamble Co shareholders re-elected their CEO, chairman, and current directors despite challenges from environmental non-profits regarding deforestation actions. Shareholders also approved executive compensation, which this year included ESG goal performance as a factor. The CEO addressed concerns about consumers switching to cheaper private-label goods due to inflation, highlighting product value and longevity.

title: Procter & Gamble founders' descendants among protesters at company headquarters
summary: Descendants of Procter & Gamble's founders protested outside the company's Cincinnati headquarters, claiming P&G was involved in human rights violations, climate inaction, and deforestation. The protest, organized by the Rainforest Action Network, saw two individuals arrested after climbing flagpoles. P&G responded by stating they value shareholder viewpoints and aim to keep forests intact, regrowing two trees for every one used.

title: From Virtual Interns to Full-Time Employees
summary: This article highlights how Procter & Gamble successfully transitioned virtual interns, such as Myles Whitmore and Vishnu Paranandi, into full-time employees during and after the pandemic. It details P&G's strategies for fostering connectedness and camaraderie among new hires in a hybrid work environment, including "Power Pairs" and enhanced onboarding. The experience also led P&G to embrace greater flexibility in its work models, recognizing that not all tasks require in-person presence.

title: Procter & Gamble submit to develop non-wood fibre products
summary: Procter & Gamble is increasing its use of alternative fibers in its products due to environmentalist pressure, committing to using bamboo fiber for its Charmin Ultra Eco toilet paper and investing over US$20mn+ over five years to develop non-wood fiber alternatives. The company also announced a commitment to using recycled fiber in its cardboard and packaging, aiming for 100% recycled fiber in packaging by 2025. These moves come after criticism regarding the environmental impact of wood-based products, particularly on the Canadian boreal forest.

title: P&G turns to AI to create digital manufacturing of the future
summary: P&G has partnered with Microsoft to transform its manufacturing operations using AI, IoT, and digital twin technology. This initiative aims to enhance product quality, optimize equipment resiliency, and improve sustainability across its global manufacturing sites. The company is scaling these smart manufacturing solutions to accelerate innovation, increase productivity, and reduce costs in its consumer goods production.

title: Band-Aids and Tylenol will have a new name on their packages
summary: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) is splitting its business into two companies, with its consumer health brands like Band-Aid and Tylenol falling under a new corporate parent named Kenvue. The new name, a combination of "Ken" and "vue," was chosen to be distinctive, memorable, and clear of trademark issues across many languages, reflecting a strategy where the corporate identity takes a backseat to its well-known product brands. The split is expected to be completed next year.

title: J&J says new Band-Aid and Tylenol company to be named Kenvue | Company Business News
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced that its new consumer-health products company, which will house brands like Band-Aid and Tylenol, will be named Kenvue. This separation of the consumer unit, with $15 billion in annual revenue, from J&J's prescription-drug and medical-device business, is expected to be completed next year. Kenvue is a portmanteau of "ken" (knowledge) and "vue" (sight), signifying its focus on consumer insights and health solutions.

title: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. stock rises Wednesday, still underperforms market
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) stock saw a 1.35% increase on Wednesday, closing at $95.27, breaking a six-day losing streak, despite the broader market also rising significantly. The stock remains $59.73 below its 52-week high and displayed mixed performance against competitors like L'Oreal S.A. ADR and Estee Lauder Cos. Cl A, while Procter & Gamble Co. remained unchanged. Trading volume for IFF exceeded its 50-day average.

title: Environmental groups ask P&G investors to vote against CEO as board chair
summary: Environmental groups are urging Procter & Gamble Co (PG.N) investors to vote against re-electing CEO Jon Moeller as board chair and two other directors, Angela Braly and Patricia Woertz, at the upcoming annual meeting. This opposition stems from claims that P&G uses excessive virgin wood pulp in its paper products and has not adequately addressed deforestation in its supply chains. The groups are advocating for an independent board chair and criticizing the company's efforts on sustainability, particularly regarding sourcing palm oil and wood pulp.

title: Defensive Characteristics Help Procter & Gamble Stand Apart
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) is highlighted as a strong, reliable investment due to its defensive characteristics, consistent dividend payments for 66 consecutive years, and diversified portfolio of essential consumer goods. Despite macroeconomic headwinds like inflation and supply chain issues, the company has maintained strong financial performance and is considered recession-resistant, making it a safe choice for long-term shareholders. The article emphasizes its ability to navigate challenging market conditions due to its established operating model and the necessity of its products.

title: P&G launches Downy Rinse & Refresh
summary: Procter & Gamble has introduced Downy Rinse & Refresh, a new product aimed at tackling odors. Company officials are touting this as one of the brand's most significant innovations in over three decades. The launch was reported by the Cincinnati Business Courier.

title: Johnson & Johnson and a New War on Consumer Protection
summary: This article details Johnson & Johnson's legal battles regarding allegations that its talcum powder caused cancer in consumers. It highlights the company's controversial "Texas two-step" bankruptcy strategy to manage tens of thousands of lawsuits and discusses the broader implications for consumer protection laws and corporate accountability.

title: Why Procter & Gamble says it chose north St. Louis for $180M expansion
summary: Procter & Gamble is expanding its St. Louis facility with a $180 million investment, driven by a local jobs program and incentives. While tax incentives played a role, the plant manager highlighted an additional key factor in the company's decision. This expansion underscores the importance of local support in attracting corporate investment.

title: 'A huge win': Consumer products giant plans $180M expansion in north St. Louis
summary: Procter & Gamble Manufacturing Co. (NYSE: PG) is planning a $180 million expansion of its existing 17-acre campus in north St. Louis, supported by state and local subsidies. The project involves $120 million in property improvements and $60 million in new equipment, aiming to retain 530 existing jobs and create 100 new ones with an average annual wage of $65,000. St. Louis successfully competed to secure this expansion.

title: 'A huge win': Consumer products giant plans $180M expansion in north St. Louis
summary: Procter & Gamble plans a $180 million expansion of its factory in north St. Louis. This development is seen as a significant win for St. Louis, contributing to urban revitalization, job creation, and training opportunities. A development official highlighted the competitive nature of securing this expansion and its role in transforming the riverfront.

title: P&G Design Brings Creative Spark to Cincinnati Festival
summary: P&G Design served as the official Creative Sponsor for the BLINK Parade in Cincinnati, Ohio, showcasing their talent and design prowess. The team contributed to the city's artistic culture by illuminating the history and heritage of P&G through various art installations and the Future City Light Spectacular BLINK Parade. This initiative highlights P&G's dual role as a "Force for Growth" and a "Force for Good" in its hometown.

title: Procter & Gamble Is Doing The Unified ID 2.0 Thing
summary: Procter & Gamble publicly announced its support for Unified ID 2.0, an open-source initiative led by The Trade Desk aiming to replace third-party cookies with hashed, encrypted email-based identifiers. P&G has already been using UID 2.0 since last year for activating anonymized identifiers linked to its first-party data in the bidstream. Attracting marketers like P&G is crucial for UID2's success, although scaling the initiative and finding an administrator remain ongoing challenges.

title: Real Deals: Procter & Gamble-leased building in Fayetteville sells for $12.7 million
summary: A 61,017-square-foot office building in Fayetteville, triple-net leased to Procter & Gamble Distributing LLC, recently sold for $12.7 million. This transaction highlights a growing real estate market, with other significant sales including a $2.25 million commercial building in Fort Smith and a $1.3 million industrial/warehouse building in Siloam Springs. The deals showcase various commercial property acquisitions and developments across Arkansas.

title: P&G CEO Jon Moeller: 'We will always try to couple both price increases with innovation'
summary: Procter & Gamble CEO Jon Moeller discusses the company's strategy amid high inflation, supply chain issues, and the war in Ukraine. Moeller emphasizes coupling price increases with innovation and highlights the company's various price offerings to retain customers. He also addresses P&G's continued, though reduced, business operations in Russia and his personal feelings about the conflict.

title: The Latest Innovations from Procter & Gamble
summary: Procter & Gamble is showcasing its latest innovations in dish care, fabric care, and hair care, emphasizing water-saving attributes and sustainable packaging. The company highlights products like Dawn Powerwash for reduced water usage, Pantene Perfec+ On No Rinse Conditioner, and the Ecoclic Box for Ariel Pods, which is fully recyclable and designed for improved accessibility. These innovations reflect P&G's commitment to environmental impact reduction and consumer-focused design.
source: Happi | Household And Personal Products Industry
source_domain: Happi | Household And Personal Products Industry

title: T.J. Maxx parent company to pay $13 million for selling recalled products
summary: TJX Companies Inc., the parent company of T.J. Maxx, Marshalls, and HomeGoods, has agreed to pay a $13 million fine for selling approximately 1,200 recalled products, including those that posed a suffocation risk to infants. The sales occurred between 2014 and 2019 at brick-and-mortar stores and online. TJX will also implement internal controls and file annual compliance reports for five years to prevent future sales of recalled items.

title: Procter & Gamble (NYSE:PG) shareholders have earned a 12% CAGR over the last five years
summary: Procter & Gamble shareholders have seen a 12% CAGR over the last five years, largely due to dividends. While the share price alone grew 56% over five years, the total shareholder return including dividends reached 79%, outperforming the general market. The article notes that EPS growth is closely aligned with share price movement, suggesting investor sentiment has remained consistent towards the company over this period.

title: Tide maker P&G misses earnings, forecasts lower growth as consumers 'scrimp'
authors: Uday Sampath Kumar and Jessica DiNapoli
summary: Procter & Gamble Co (P&G) missed quarterly earnings estimates and forecast lower sales growth due to surging transportation, commodity costs, and consumer cutbacks. The company reported a resurgence of shoppers buying cheaper store brand items and noted that consumers are buying less after rounds of price hikes. P&G expects significant headwinds for fiscal 2023, including a $3.3 billion hit from a stronger dollar and higher costs.

title: US: Colgate, P&G rejig price tactics to keep cash-strapped shoppers
summary: Major consumer product manufacturers like Colgate-Palmolive and Procter & Gamble are adjusting their pricing strategies to retain cash-strapped shoppers amidst recession fears. This includes targeting discounts during specific times of the month when consumers get paid and promoting premium products early in the month, then budget items later. Companies are also increasing spending on discounts, considering smaller portion sizes, and emphasizing the value of their premium national brands over cheaper alternatives to prevent consumers from switching to store brands or dollar stores.

title: P&G uses Life Cycle Assessment for Sustainable Packaging Design
summary: Procter & Gamble uses carbon-based Life Cycle Assessments (LCAs) to guide its sustainable packaging design and innovation, aiming for 100% recycled or reusable packaging by 2030 and a 50% reduction in virgin petroleum plastic. Victoria Jung, Packaging Technology Leader for P&G’s Surface Care Portfolio, highlights how this approach has led to significant plastic reductions in Swiffer and Mr. Clean products, and innovative designs for Dawn to encourage sustainable consumer behavior. The company also emphasizes continuous innovation and partnerships, such as with TerraCycle, to achieve its ambitious sustainability goals.

title: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. stock falls Monday, still outperforms market
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) saw its stock fall by 0.31% on Monday, closing at $116.22, despite the broader market experiencing a more significant downturn. This marked the third consecutive day of losses for IFF, which remains $40.86 below its 52-week high. The company's performance was mixed compared to competitors, with Procter & Gamble Co. seeing gains while L'Oreal S.A. ADR and Estee Lauder Cos. Cl A both declined.

title: A new way iconic brands like Procter & Gamble, Nokia are cashing in on R&D moonshots
summary: Iconic brands like Procter & Gamble and Nokia are utilizing a new approach to monetize their R&D innovations through Innventure, a firm that builds startups around corporate technologies. This model allows parent companies to become key customers of the spun-out businesses, offering a less risky alternative to traditional venture capital. Notable examples include Accelsius, leveraging Nokia's cooling technology, and PureCycle Technologies and AeroFlexx, born from P&G's sustainability R&D.

title: Black Swan Data Closes $18.5 Million in Funding
summary: Black Swan Data, a London-based SaaS company specializing in predicting consumer behavior using social data, secured an $18.5 million growth investment. The funding round was led by Oxx, with participation from existing investors AlbionVC, Blackstone, Mitsui, and Lloyds. This investment will support the development of advanced features for its Trendscope platform and aid in its expansion into the US market.

title: What's the Impact of the Strong Dollar on My Portfolio?
summary: The strong U.S. dollar, experiencing its biggest rally in 20 years, negatively impacts non-U.S. fund returns and profitability for American companies operating overseas. While it offers advantages for consumers traveling abroad, investors in international stocks and bonds face challenges due to unfavorable exchange rates and increased repayment costs for dollar-denominated debt. Despite the difficulties, some Morningstar analysts suggest currency hedging can minimize volatility, and others view the current currency weakness as an attractive buying opportunity for international funds.

title: Is Procter & Gamble Co (PG) A Great Value Stock?
summary: This article examines Procter & Gamble Co (PG) as a potential value stock, highlighting its strong brand portfolio and consistent performance.
