title: P&G Earns Seventh Straight Gartner Supply Chain Mastery Award
summary: P&G has received its seventh consecutive Gartner Supply Chain Mastery Award, an achievement that highlights its long-term excellence in supply chain management. This recognition comes despite the extreme disruptions caused by the pandemic, which tested P&G's supply chain significantly. P&G is one of only five companies, including Apple, Amazon, McDonald’s, and Unilever, to be recognized in the elite "Master" category, which acknowledges consistent top performance over many years.

title: McDonald’s, Byron Allen dispute continues amid scrutiny into QSR ad-spending practices
summary: McDonald's announced plans to more than double its investments in diverse media partners following a discrimination lawsuit filed by Byron Allen's Allen Media Group. The lawsuit alleges racial stereotyping and refusal to contract based on race, seeking $10 billion in damages and claiming McDonald's operates a tiered advertising structure. McDonald's aims to increase its national advertising spending with Black-, Hispanic-, Asian Pacific American-, women- and LGBTQ-owned platforms to 10% by 2024, specifically boosting allocation for Black-owned businesses from 2% to 5%.

title: Here's Why You Should Hold on to AptarGroup (ATR) Stock Now
summary: AptarGroup (ATR) is expected to continue benefiting from increased demand for hygiene products and vaccine components due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's strong Q1 earnings, positive Q2 guidance, strategic acquisitions, and innovative product launches further strengthen its investment profile. AptarGroup currently holds a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) and a VGM Score of B, indicating favorable investment potential when combined with its rank.

title: Short seller's report targets PureCycle
summary: Hindenburg Research, a short seller, has published a report alleging that PureCycle Technologies is an example of executives enriching themselves while presenting unproven technology and unrealistic financial projections to public markets. PureCycle, a publicly traded company licensing PP purification technology from Procter & Gamble, immediately denied the allegations. The report led to a significant drop in PureCycle's stock price, prompting law firms to seek to represent investors who lost money.

title: How Proctor & Gamble Reacted to News Meghan Markle Called Out Sexist Ad
summary: Proctor & Gamble reacted positively to Meghan Markle's childhood letter calling out sexist advertising, noting they were "moved" by her activism for gender equality. The company has now partnered with Meghan and Prince Harry's Archewell Foundation to work on gender equality initiatives, underscoring their commitment to using advertising as a force for good. This collaboration follows Markle's successful campaign as a schoolgirl in 1993, which led P&G to change a sexist commercial.

title: How Meghan Markle’s Procter & Gamble Partnership Follows Woke-Washing Claim
summary: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's Archewell Foundation announced a multiyear partnership with Procter & Gamble, a move that harks back to Markle's childhood criticism of the company's sexist advertising. This partnership is now drawing attention for P&G's recent "woke washing" marketing strategies, where it promotes social causes to sell products. Critics, including Piers Morgan, have previously taken issue with P&G's socially conscious campaigns, such as Gillette's toxic masculinity ad, raising questions about the authenticity of such corporate efforts.

title: Kroger Celebrates Small Business Week and Offers Retail Partnership Guidebook to Advance Supplier Inclusion
summary: Kroger announced new initiatives and progress in its supplier inclusion program, achieving $4.1 billion in diverse supplier spend in 2020 and introducing 107 new diverse suppliers. The company launched a Small Business Resource Guide and held its 3rd annual Supplier Inclusion Innovation Summit to further support diverse-owned enterprises. Kroger is also piloting a Multicultural Entrepreneurship Development program and will launch a Go Fresh & Local Supplier Accelerator.

title: Honest Co. CEO ready to face big-name competition like P&G and Revlon with 'clean' brand strength
summary: Honest Co.'s shares soared in its Nasdaq debut, but the company faces significant competition from established players like P&G and Revlon. Despite the successful IPO, one research group considers the stock 'overvalued,' indicating potential challenges ahead. The CEO is prepared to leverage the strength of its 'clean' brand to compete in the market.

title: Procter & Gamble raising prices on baby care, feminine care products
summary: Procter & Gamble announced price increases on baby care, feminine care, and adult incontinence products, including popular brands like Pampers, Luvs, Tampax, and Always. These price hikes, expected to be in the mid-to-high single-digit percentages, will begin in September to offset rising commodity costs and supply bottlenecks. Other companies like 3M and Coca-Cola are also implementing similar price adjustments.

title: Diapers, Cereal and, Yes, Toilet Paper Are Going to Get More Expensive (Published 2021)
summary: Major consumer goods companies like Procter & Gamble, Kimberly-Clark, and General Mills are raising prices on essential products due to increased commodity costs, supply-chain issues, and freight expenses. This shift reflects a change in how companies are responding to demand during the pandemic, with retailers now passing on higher costs to consumers rather than absorbing them as they did pre-pandemic. The pandemic-induced chaos in global shipping and a rapid shift in consumer buying habits are cited as primary drivers for these price increases.

title: Procter & Gamble Is One of the 2021 TIME100 Most Influential Companies | TIME
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) was recognized as one of the 2021 TIME100 Most Influential Companies due to its significant performance during the pandemic. The company saw a banner year with $71 billion in sales, a 6% increase, driven by high demand for its household products like Charmin and Tide. Additionally, P&G repurposed its manufacturing capabilities to produce hundreds of thousands of face shields for healthcare workers.

title: Procter & Gamble Acquires Voost Vitamins
summary: Procter & Gamble has acquired Voost, an Australian brand specializing in effervescent vitamins, for an undisclosed sum. This move allows P&G to expand its portfolio in the growing vitamins, minerals, and supplements industry, particularly targeting the Australian market. Voost, founded in 2013, has achieved significant year-on-year sales growth of 50 percent, making it a leader in the effervescent vitamins subcategory in Australia.

title: P&G plans to quickly scale e-commerce capabilities as digital sales grow 50%
summary: Procter & Gamble reported a 50% year-over-year growth in e-commerce sales during its fiscal third-quarter, now accounting for 14% of global sales. This growth is driving P&G to rapidly scale its e-commerce capabilities, influencing areas like packaging design, to meet evolving consumer trends accelerated by the pandemic. Other major CPGs like Unilever are also increasing investments in high-growth digital segments.

title: Sherwin-Williams Shareholders Elect New Director
summary: The Sherwin-Williams Company announced that Aaron M. Powell was elected to its Board of Directors at the company's Annual Meeting of Shareholders. Powell, currently President, Asia-Pacific Consumer Business for Kimberly-Clark Corporation, will also serve on the Board's Audit Committee. John G. Morikis, Chairman, President and CEO of Sherwin-Williams, highlighted Powell's extensive experience in global markets, operations, sales, marketing, and digital expertise.

title: Procter & Gamble announced as Major League Soccer sponsor
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has inked a multi-year, multifaceted sponsorship deal with Major League Soccer (MLS). This partnership will see P&G sponsor key MLS events like the All-Star Game and Campeones Cup, as well as the Mexico men’s national team’s US tour. The collaboration aims to leverage P&G's brand portfolio to connect with fans and help make soccer more accessible.

title: Procter & Gamble Will Raise Prices in September
summary: Procter & Gamble announced it will increase prices on various household staples, including baby products, adult diapers, and feminine-care brands, starting in September. This move, making it the latest and largest consumer-products company to do so, is a response to rising costs for raw materials like resin and pulp, as well as higher transportation expenses. The price increases come as the company reports slowing growth in its latest financial quarter.

title: Procter & Gamble to raises prices on baby care, feminine care and adult incontinence products
summary: Procter & Gamble announced price increases of 5 to 9% on paper products and mid-to-high single-digit percentages on baby care, feminine care, and adult incontinence products, effective mid-September, to offset rising commodity costs. The company reported a 12.1% increase in profit to $3.3 billion and sales up 5.2% to $18.1 billion, also boosting its quarterly dividend by 10%. P&G is the world's largest consumer products company, making products like Pampers and Crest.

title: Procter & Gamble Will Raise Prices On Baby And Feminine Care Products In September
summary: Procter & Gamble announced it will raise prices on baby care, feminine care, and adult incontinence products starting in September to offset rising commodity prices. This move follows similar announcements from competitors Kimberly-Clark and Coca-Cola, as companies expect a short-term bump in inflation as the economy recovers. The price increases will be mid-to-high single-digit percentages and will vary by brand.

title: Procter & Gamble earnings beat as consumers hang on to pandemic cleaning habits; price hikes ahead
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) exceeded Wall Street's expectations for its fiscal third-quarter earnings and revenue, driven by sustained consumer demand for cleaning supplies and revitalized interest in beauty products. The company announced upcoming price hikes on some products in autumn to offset rising commodity and freight costs. Despite the positive earnings, shares dipped slightly in premarket trading.

title: Procter & Gamble Splashes $3bn on Supplier Diversity
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has announced plans to spend $3 billion with diverse-owned businesses by 2030, building on its prior investment of $2.8 billion between 2008 and 2020. This initiative aims to increase diversity within its own supply base and encourage its suppliers to also diversify their networks, particularly increasing investment in women-owned businesses globally. P&G views a diverse supply chain as a critical element for innovation, market growth, and creating positive socio-economic impacts.

title: Fragrance Creators to Present Sean Broderick of Procter & Gamble With Extraordinary Leadership Award
summary: Fragrance Creators Association will present Sean Broderick of Procter & Gamble with a special Extraordinary Leadership Award for his instrumental role in helping the industry navigate and continue operations during the COVID-19 pandemic. Broderick facilitated coordination among key industry organizations and served as a vital resource for the fragrance value chain, providing guidance and data during bi-weekly leadership meetings. The award will be formally presented at Fragrance Creators' 2021 Mid-Year Business Meeting on July 22, 2021.

title: P&G Declares Dividend Increase
summary: The Procter & Gamble Company (NYSE:PG) announced an increased quarterly dividend of $0.8698 per share, representing a 10% increase from the previous dividend. This marks the 65th consecutive year P&G has increased its dividend and the 131st consecutive year it has paid a dividend. The company highlighted its commitment to returning cash to shareholders.

title: Major League Soccer lands a top corporate sponsorship with Procter & Gamble
summary: Major League Soccer (MLS) has secured a five-year corporate sponsorship deal with Procter & Gamble (P&G), estimated to be worth between $80 million and $100 million. This partnership aims to help MLS recover from significant Covid-19 losses and leverage P&G's brand strength to promote the league to a growing North American soccer audience. P&G will sponsor key MLS events and use its product brands like Gillette, Old Spice, and Crest to promote the league, aligning with MLS's strategy to appeal to younger, diverse sports fans.

title: P&G, Dove Push for More Equitable Representation in Media
summary: Procter & Gamble has launched "Widen the Screen," a platform to increase inclusion of Black creators and improve portrayals of Black life in media through new films, initiatives, and investments in Black-owned media. Simultaneously, Dove South Africa is challenging other brands to adopt more diverse talent in their ad campaigns by offering to subsidize booking costs, building on its years of promoting broader representations of beauty. Both companies aim to drive more equitable representation and challenge narrow beauty ideals within the advertising and media industries.

title: General Motors Pledges to Devote More Ad Dollars to Black-Owned Media
summary: General Motors announced its commitment to significantly increase its advertising spending with Black-owned media outlets, quadrupling the percentage from 2% to 8% by 2025. This decision follows pressure from Black media leaders and aims to foster greater diversity and inclusion in its marketing efforts. GM will also launch an "upfront" process for diverse media owners to submit business proposals.

title: Kimberly-Clark says Cottonelle, Scott toilet paper price hikes coming
summary: Kimberly-Clark announced price increases "in the mid-to-high single digits" for Cottonelle, Scott toilet paper, and other baby/adult care products in North America, effective by late June. This move is necessary to offset significant commodity cost inflation. The announcement comes amidst recent concerns over potential toilet paper shortages due to the Suez Canal blockage and prior pandemic-induced stockpiling.

title: Procter & Gamble’s environmental controversy escalates with protest in company’s hometown
summary: Activists from Stand.earth recently escalated their protest against Procter & Gamble in Cincinnati, broadcasting radio messages and holding demonstrations to highlight the company's alleged role in deforestation and human rights abuses through its supply chains. This protest occurred after P&G's "inadequate plans" to address these issues were announced, following a shareholder directive raised in October 2020. The activists accuse P&G of greenwashing and failing to commit to ending relationships with suppliers involved in destroying critical primary forests and violating human rights.

title: Shoppers Start to See Effect of Higher Commodity Costs
summary: Consumers are beginning to experience the impact of rising commodity prices as manufacturers, including Kimberly-Clark, General Mills, and Hormel, pass increased costs onto shoppers. Kimberly-Clark specifically announced plans to raise prices across its North America consumer-products business to offset higher raw-material expenses. This trend reflects the strain Felt by companies as commodity prices climb.

title: Colgate taps into the ‘oral beauty’ trend with new sub-brand for Gen Zers
summary: Colgate-Palmolive launched Co. by Colgate, a new oral care sub-brand targeting Gen Z consumers, sold exclusively through Ulta Beauty and its DTC site. The brand aims to tap into the "oral beauty" trend by merging oral care with self-care, as Gen Z increasingly views beauty as a way to fulfill self-care needs. Co. by Colgate features seven products priced from $8-$129 and plans to donate a portion of sales to charity, while also focusing on understanding and engaging with its target demographic.

title: Better Buy: Procter & Gamble or All 30 Dow Jones Stocks?
summary: This article argues that due to current market conditions, which are becoming a "stock picker's market," Procter & Gamble (NYSE:PG) is a better investment than the entire Dow Jones Industrial Average. P&G offers safety, reliability, and stability, with its consumer staples products and low beta making it less susceptible to market-wide downturns. The author suggests adjusting portfolios to prioritize defensive stocks like P&G given perceived market overvaluation and potential for correction.

title: P&G Aims to Improve Portrayal of “Black Life” on Screen, Expands Inclusion Efforts for Black Creators
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has launched "Widen The Screen," an initiative to improve the portrayal of Black life in advertising, film, and television by increasing Black creators' inclusion and investment in Black-owned media. The program includes new films, talent development platforms, and partnerships aimed at combating stereotypes and fostering more diverse storytelling. This expands on P&G's previous efforts to promote racial equity and aims to create more accurate and dynamic representations of Black individuals.

title: Procter & Gamble’s New ‘Widen The Screen’ Program Aims To Diversify The Portrayal Of Black People In Advertising And Entertainment
summary: Procter & Gamble has launched "Widen The Screen," a new program aimed at increasing the accurate and diverse portrayal of Black people in advertising and entertainment. The initiative seeks to invest in Black directors, actors, crews, and media, fostering greater representation within the creative and media supply chain. P&G is partnering with various companies and organizations, including Spring Hill, Saturday Morning, and the Tribeca Film Festival, and also increasing investment in Black-owned media companies.

title: Who will replace Procter & Gamble's CEO David Taylor?
summary: This article discusses the potential succession planning for Procter & Gamble's CEO David Taylor, who is nearing retirement age. While there's no immediate pressure for a change given P&G's strong performance, the article identifies Jon Moeller, the current COO, as a frontrunner and also highlights several other key executives, including three women and two Asia-born leaders, who are being groomed for top positions. It also details the recent financial performance of various P&G business units and touches on Taylor's tenure and the company's past challenges and successes.

title: PureCycle Technologies completes business combination with Roth CH Acquisition I Co. and will begin trading on Nasdaq
summary: PureCycle Technologies has completed its business combination with Roth CH Acquisition I Co. and will begin trading on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "PCT." This transaction provides PureCycle with increased capital market access to scale its proprietary recycling process for polypropylene, transforming plastic waste into virgin-like resin. The company aims to revolutionize polypropylene recycling, a material with broad applications but a low current recycling rate.

title: Stick to the Fundamentals with the Value-Focused 'VTV'
summary: The article highlights the Vanguard Value ETF (VTV) as a promising investment option for those looking to capitalize on the ongoing value stock comeback. VTV focuses on large-cap value stocks, offering stability during downturns and capturing upside potential in a recovering economic climate. The fund, which tracks the CRSP U.S. Large Cap Value Index, is up significantly in the past year and provides a convenient way to invest in large value stocks with stable revenues and dividend potential.

title: Kimberly-Clark Names Robert Long as Chief Research and Development Officer
summary: Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced the appointment of Robert Long as its new Chief Research and Development Officer, effective March 15, 2021. In this newly created role, Long will oversee global research, development, innovation, and quality functions, reporting directly to CEO Mike Hsu and serving on the executive leadership team. Long brings over four decades of experience from companies like The Coca-Cola Company and Procter & Gamble, where he held senior R&D and innovation leadership positions.

title: Hershey threatens to suspend non-compliant suppliers in effort to cut deforestation
summary: Hershey has implemented a companywide policy to eliminate deforestation across its raw material supply chain by 2030, threatening to suspend or remove non-compliant suppliers. This new holistic approach replaces its previous commodity-by-commodity strategy and is part of a broader ESG agenda that includes reducing Scope 3 emissions and packaging weight. The policy outlines specific requirements for suppliers, including commitments to reforest, respect human rights, and avoid illegal harvesting, with a focus on high-risk commodities like cocoa, palm oil, soy, and pulp and paper.

title: Top Women Profile: Tabata Gomez
summary: Tabata Gomez, Chief Marketing Officer at Stanley Black & Decker, shares her journey from cosmetics to power tools and her efforts to promote diversity and gender equality in the hardware industry. She discusses the successful re-launch of the Craftsman brand, challenges to unconscious bias, and Stanley Black & Decker's commitment to gender parity. Gomez also reflects on teaching her son about breaking stereotypes and achieving success.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch elects Kenneth Robinson to its Board of Directors
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch has elected Kenneth Robinson as an independent director to its Board of Directors, where he will also serve on the audit and finance committee. Robinson brings over 40 years of consumer retail experience, including roles at Exelon Corporation and Procter & Gamble. His election expands the board to 13 members, and he expressed enthusiasm for the company's progressive stance on sustainability and diversity.

title: Global Feminine Hygiene Products Market to Grow by $7.11 Billion During 2020-2024 | 32% Growth to Come From APAC | Technavio
summary: Technavio projects the global feminine hygiene products market to grow by $7.11 billion from 2020-2024, at a CAGR of over 4%. APAC is expected to contribute 32% of this growth, driven by key markets like China and Japan. The sanitary napkins segment will see significant growth due to government initiatives promoting hygiene awareness.

title: Clearwater Paper Corporation raises 4.79% on January 12
summary: Clearwater Paper Corporation saw its shares jump 4.79% on January 12, closing at $41.78. The company, which manufactures private label tissue, paperboard, and pulp-based products, traded approximately 127,201 shares. The gain increased its market cap to $692.43 million, with shares trading between $43.16 and $11.89 over the past year.

title: Kroger and Cintas halt political contributions, P&G may change future support
summary: Kroger and Cintas announced they are halting political donations following the riots in Washington, D.C., with Kroger reviewing its PAC-giving philosophy and Cintas reviewing its criteria and strategy. Procter & Gamble also signaled it might change its future political support based on actions undermining democratic processes. These Cincinnati-based companies join a growing list of corporations rethinking their financial support for politicians after the Capitol riot.

title: Get High Dividend Exposure with the HDEF ETF
summary: The article discusses the Xtrackers MSCI EAFE High Dividend Yield Equity ETF (HDEF) as an option for investors seeking high dividend exposure with international diversification. HDEF offers exposure to developed markets outside the U.S., focusing on high-dividend stocks while hedging against currency risk. This strategy aims to provide stable dividend payments, exemplified by its top holding, Unilever PLC.

title: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. stock rises Wednesday, outperforms market
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) stock saw a 1.07% increase on Wednesday, closing at $112.12 and outperforming the broader market. Despite this gain, the stock remains $31.75 below its 52-week high. Competitors such as Procter & Gamble Co., L'Oreal S.A. ADR, and Estee Lauder Cos. Cl A also experienced gains on the same day.

title: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. stock rises Wednesday, outperforms market
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) stock rose 1.07% on Wednesday, outperforming the broader market. Despite a mixed trading session for the S&P 500 and Dow Jones, IFF achieved its second consecutive day of gains. The stock closed below its 52-week high but showed a mixed performance compared to competitors like Procter & Gamble Co., L'Oreal S.A. ADR, and Estee Lauder Cos. Cl A.

title: Coca-Cola kicks off massive agency review to 'fundamentally transform' its marketing
summary: Coca-Cola has launched a comprehensive global review of its media and creative planning and buying practices, along with its agency appointments. This initiative aims to enhance effectiveness and efficiency across various marketing investments, including media, creative, and production, as part of the company's digital transformation. While expected to generate cost savings, the primary goal is a fundamental redesign of its marketing model and consolidation of third-party agencies.

title: Colgate-Palmolive’s Developed Markets Remained a Drag in 1Q17
summary: Colgate-Palmolive's sales in developed markets, including North America and Europe, experienced a decline in 1Q17, largely due to falling volumes and lower pricing, impacting overall financial performance. While North America was hit hardest, European sales showed a sequential improvement despite adverse currency fluctuations. The company maintained market leadership in oral care and saw success with new product launches despite these challenges.

title: Amazon is price gouging cleaning products for the second COVID wave
summary: During the second COVID-19 wave, Amazon sellers are price gouging cleaning products from name brands like Clorox, Bounty, and Charmin, while generic alternatives remain relatively more stable. Clorox wipe prices, for instance, have surged over 200% since January, reaching as high as $50 for a pack. This practice is occurring despite earlier efforts by companies like Clorox to address price gouging on the platform.

title: Thermo Fisher Scientific Elects New Director to Board
summary: Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. has announced the election of R. Alexandra "Alex" Keith to its board of directors, increasing the board's total to 13 members. Ms. Keith currently serves as CEO of Procter & Gamble's global Beauty business and brings extensive experience in leadership and brand-building. Chairman and CEO Marc N. Casper highlighted her visionary leadership and focus on results as key assets for Thermo Fisher Scientific's global brand strategy.

title: |Tesla to Join S&P 500 Next Month as Largest-Ever New Member
summary: |Tesla Inc. (TSLA) is set to join the S&P 500 index on December 21, becoming the largest company ever added to the gauge. This announcement follows months of speculation and a significant rally in the stock this year, elevating the electric vehicle pioneer's market value to nearly $390 billion. Tesla's inclusion is expected to greatly broaden its investor base and make it one of the index's most influential constituents.

title: Rodolfo Spielmann joins NatureSweet as president and CEO
summary: Rodolfo Spielmann has been appointed president and CEO of NatureSweet Tomatoes in San Antonio. He brings over 23 years of experience from major consumer packaged goods companies, including Proctor & Gamble, Heinz, Del Monte, and Mars, where he focused on growth and development. Spielmann recently attended the Fresh Summit to engage with customers and explore partnership opportunities.

title: ­Clorox lifts forecast after best sales jump in over 20 years
summary: ­Clorox reported its strongest quarterly sales growth in over two decades, leading the company to raise its full-year sales and profit forecasts. This surge is attributed to increased demand for disinfectants and other cleaning products due to the Covid-19 pandemic, as well as higher sales of products like Glad trash bags and charcoal. Despite running factories round the clock, Clorox, like its peers, is still struggling to fully meet the elevated consumer demand.

title: Ecolab’s Doug Baker to Retire After 16-Year Run as CEO
summary: Doug Baker, CEO of Ecolab for 16 years, will retire on January 1st, with President and COO Christophe Beck taking over. Baker is credited with significantly growing the company's global sales, overseeing major acquisitions, and playing a prominent role in the Minnesota business community and St. Paul's community life. Christophe Beck, an Ecolab veteran since 2007, is set to continue Baker's vision for the company.

title: J.M. Smucker selling Crisco to Green Giant owner for $550 million
summary: J.M. Smucker Co. is selling its Crisco brand to B&G Foods Inc. for $550 million in a cash deal. This divestiture aligns with Smucker's strategy to exit the U.S. baking category and focus on pet food, coffee, and snacks. Crisco generated approximately $270 million in sales for Smucker's 2020 fiscal year.

title: How Clorox’s new CEO plans to turn disinfectant wipes into future wins
summary: New Clorox CEO Linda Rendle aims to leverage the increased demand for disinfectant wipes during the COVID-19 pandemic to accelerate the company's multiyear "Ignite" growth plan. This strategy focuses on innovation, expanding into new markets like professional cleaning, and building on its health and wellness product portfolio. The article highlights how Clorox is adapting to capitalize on current trends while maintaining its long-term objectives for revenue growth and profitability.

title: Icahn Automotive Appoints Elisa Bannon-Jones Chief People Officer and Deborah Brundage Chief Marketing Officer
summary: Icahn Automotive has announced the appointment of Elisa Bannon-Jones as Chief People Officer and Deborah Brundage as Chief Marketing Officer. Bannon-Jones will lead human resources strategy, while Brundage will direct marketing, communications, and customer experience. These appointments are part of an ongoing plan to separate Icahn Automotive into distinct Parts and Service companies, strengthening leadership for the Service division.

title: Amazon launches "Climate Pledge Friendly" program
summary: Amazon is launching "Climate Pledge Friendly," a new program labeling over 25,000 products with sustainability certifications, making it easier for customers to find eco-friendly options. The initiative includes a new certification called "Compact by Design" which focuses on product efficiency to reduce carbon emissions through better packaging and design. This program supports Amazon's commitment to be net-zero carbon by 2040 and aligns with the Paris Agreement.

title: Procter & Gamble, Unilever and Colgate-Palmolive top chart as ‘world’s worst offenders’ for plastic pollution
summary: Procter & Gamble, Unilever, and Colgate-Palmolive have been identified as some of the top global plastic polluters in a report by The Changing Markets Foundation. The report, titled 'Talking Trash: The Corporate Playbook of False Solutions,' criticizes these companies for allegedly obstructing plastic waste legislation while their initiatives fall short of addressing the crisis. The companies are accused of producing substantial amounts of plastic packaging annually and using the pandemic to push for increased plastic use.

title: Shareholders mount class action lawsuit against Coty
summary: Coty, Inc. and some of its officers are facing a class action lawsuit from shareholders. The lawsuit claims the company provided misleading information and overpaid for its acquisitions of the P&G specialty beauty business and Kylie Cosmetics, and lacked adequate infrastructure to integrate them. The lawsuit seeks damages for alleged violations of federal securities laws.

title: Digimarc to serve as principal technology for HolyGrail 2.0 initiative
summary: Digimarc's automatic identification platform has been selected as the principal technology for the "HolyGrail 2.0" initiative. This cross-value chain effort aims to evaluate how digital watermarking can improve the sorting and recycling rates for packaging within the European Union. Major brands like P&G, Nestle, PepsiCo, and Danone are leading the initiative with over 85 participating companies.

title: Warren Buffett auctioned off a wallet containing a stock tip for $210,000 in 1999
summary: Billionaire investor Warren Buffett auctioned off his wallet for $210,000 in 1999 to benefit the Omaha charity Girls Inc. The wallet contained a Geico business card, an expired Hooters discount pass, and a stock tip for First Industrial Realty Trust. The winning bidder shared the stock tip with others who donated to the charity, and Buffett himself invested $43 million in the company before eventually selling his stake.

title: Shweta Shukla Named Senior Director and Head, Corporate Affairs, Asia Pacific, Middle East, and Africa for Kellogg’s
summary: Kellogg Company has appointed Shweta Shukla as Senior Director and Head of Corporate Affairs for Asia Pacific, Middle East, and Africa. In this role, Shukla will oversee Sustainability, Philanthropy, Government Affairs, and Communications, leveraging her 20 years of experience from companies like Unilever, Procter & Gamble, and Kimberly-Clark. Her focus will include Kellogg's Heart & Soul Sustainability Strategy, which pledges to support climate-smart farming, cut food waste, and utilize responsibly sourced ingredients.

title: Ecolab CEO joins Mayo Clinic Board of Trustees
summary: Douglas M. Baker, Jr., Chairman and CEO of Ecolab Inc., was elected as a public trustee to the Mayo Clinic Board of Trustees. He brings decades of national and global leadership experience to the board. Baker's extensive background includes leadership roles at Ecolab and board positions with Target Corporation and the National Association of Manufacturers.

title: New Clorox CEO brings female leadership of top companies to record 38
summary: Linda Rendle will become the new CEO of The Clorox Company in September, raising the number of female Fortune 500 leaders to a record 38. This appointment follows a 15% sales spike for Clorox during the initial months of the coronavirus pandemic. Rendle plans to expand the company's brand into wellness and nutraceuticals and enhance the disposability of cleaning wipes.

title: Clorox tops corporate reputation ranking as demand soars over COVID-19
summary: Clorox has risen to the No. 1 spot on the annual Axios-Harris Poll 100 Corporate Reputation Rankings due to soaring demand for its disinfectant products amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Consumers rewarded companies that provided essential goods and services during the crisis, leading to a shift in rankings where health and safety became paramount. Other companies focused on essentials like Hershey, Publix, and Proctor & Gamble also saw strong showings, while those that faced safety concerns or failed to meet consumer needs, such as Boeing and Juul Labs, significantly dropped.

title: Coca-Cola pauses advertising on all social media platforms globally
summary: Coca-Cola announced it would pause advertising on all social media platforms globally for at least 30 days to reassess its policies and demand greater accountability from its partners. This decision comes amidst a growing advertiser boycott, #StopHateForProfit, against platforms like Facebook and Instagram over their handling of hate speech and misinformation. Other major companies, including Unilever, Levi's, Dockers, and Hershey's, have also announced similar advertising pauses or spending cuts.

title: Unilever, Johnson & Johnson will pull or rebrand skin-lightening creams in India
summary: Unilever, Johnson & Johnson, and L'Oreal are rebranding or discontinuing some of their skin-lightening products in India and Asia following growing controversy and global protests against racial discrimination. Hindustan Unilever will remove the word "Fair" from its "Fair & Lovely" brand, while Johnson & Johnson has already pulled products with "Fairness" labels. L'Oreal is also removing terms like "white," "fair," and "light" from similar products, aiming for a more inclusive vision of beauty.

title: Johnson & Johnson drops skin-whitening creams
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced it would stop selling skin-whitening creams in Asia and the Middle East, citing renewed social pressure amidst global discussions on racial inequality. The company stated that product names suggesting "fair" or "white" as better contradict their view that "healthy skin is beautiful skin." This decision affects product lines like Clean & Clear Fairness and Neutrogena Fine Fairness, though existing stock may still be available on shelves.

title: Colgate-Palmolive to review product's name that translates to 'Black people toothpaste'
summary: Colgate-Palmolive announced it would review the name of its "Darlie" toothpaste, a popular brand in Asia, which translates to "Black people toothpaste." This decision follows renewed criticism over racial inequality and stereotyping, and comes after similar moves by other American brands to reassess offensive branding. The product, co-owned with Hawley & Hazel, had previously changed its name and logo from "Darkie" and a minstrel singer in blackface in 1989 due to public backlash.

title: PepsiCo Appoints New APAC CEO from Walmart China
summary: PepsiCo has appointed Wern-Yuen Tan, formerly of Walmart China, as its new CEO of Asia Pacific, Australia, New Zealand, and China (APAC), effective June 15, 2020. Tan will be responsible for overseeing all of PepsiCo's operations in the region, bringing extensive experience in retail, food service, and consulting. Ram Krishnan, the previous APAC CEO, will transition full-time to his role as global chief commercial officer of PepsiCo.

title: Kevin O'Leary: If you're worried about dividend cuts, it's 'time to use actively managed ETFs'
summary: Kevin O'Leary suggests that actively managed ETFs are a valuable tool for investors concerned about dividend cuts and market volatility, particularly in an uncertain market environment. He highlights O'Shares FTSE U.S. Quality Dividend ETF (OUSA) as an example of an actively managed fund that focuses on companies with high-quality balance sheets and lower likelihood of cutting dividends. O'Leary emphasizes that in these times, quality really matters and active management can help cherry-pick sound investments.

title: CVS Gets Serious About Stress Relief Products
summary: CVS Health Corp. is expanding its over-the-counter health and wellness aisles with a new “Calm and Comfort Wellness” section, featuring stress-relief products like weighted blankets, essential oils, and supplements. This initiative, which began in 2019 and is rolling out to 4,500 stores, aims to make proactive health and wellness more accessible. The expansion includes new brands like R3Set, a supplement line developed by former Bayer executives, catering to increased consumer demand for stress and anxiety relief during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Procter & Gamble settles in Charmin lawsuit
summary: Procter & Gamble has settled a class-action lawsuit concerning its Charmin Freshmates Flushable Wipes. The lawsuit, initiated in 2017, alleged false marketing of the wipes as "flushable," leading to sewer system blockages. P&G stated they were not found liable and settled to efficiently close the matter, despite not accepting fault.

title: Toilet paper maker Procter & Gamble increases dividend
summary: Procter & Gamble announced a 6% increase in its quarterly dividend to $0.7907 a share and moved up its earnings release date to April 17. Following this announcement, the company's shares rose 1.4% in extended trading and closed up 4.3%. Procter & Gamble produces various consumer goods, including the popular Charmin toilet paper brand.

title: Two of region’s largest firms agree on $224M deal
summary: Two major firms in the region have agreed to a deal worth $224 million, with a potential to reach $250 million. The article mentions Joe Raver, CEO of Hillenbrand Inc., in connection with the transaction.

title: J.M. Smucker hires new chief operating officer
summary: J.M. Smucker Co. announced it has hired John Brase as its chief operating officer, effective April 13. Brase, previously from Procter & Gamble, brings nearly 30 years of experience in the consumer goods industry. He will oversee the company's U.S. business segments and operations, with a base salary of $700,000 plus significant bonuses and stock grants.

title: J.M. Smucker hires P&G veteran as its new chief operating officer
summary: J.M. Smucker Co. has appointed John Brase, a veteran from Procter & Gamble, as its new chief operating officer. This newly created position was established last November during a management reorganization. Brase will oversee the company's U.S. business segments, including pet food and snacks, coffee, consumer foods, and its Away From Home food-service business, as well as operations and supply-chain functions.

title: Carlyle Group’s $1.4 Billion Folly: Inside The Biggest Buyout Loss In Washington, D.C. Firm’s 33-Year History
summary: Carlyle Group's $1.4 billion equity investment in Acosta was completely wiped out, marking the biggest buyout loss in the firm's 33-year history. Acosta, a food broker, faced declining revenues due to shifting consumer preferences and aggressive cost-cutting by clients, leading to a bankruptcy filing despite Carlyle's efforts. The article highlights the growing trend of private equity firms trading companies among themselves and the risks associated with high debt levels in such deals.

title: Dividend Growth Investing Made Easy with ETFs
summary: This article, a guest post by Tom of Dividends Diversify, explains how dividend growth investing can be made easy through the use of Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs). It highlights the benefits of diversification offered by ETFs and discusses several popular dividend ETFs such as VYM, VIG, VYMI, and NOBL, outlining their characteristics and investment strategies. The article also touches on considerations for Canadian investors regarding withholding taxes and briefly mentions individual stock holdings.

title: Ad of the Week: Jif's GIF drive is the best peanut butter campaign of all time
summary: Jif has launched a campaign leveraging the long-standing pronunciation debate between "Jif" and "GIF" by partnering with GIPHY. The campaign, which includes limited-edition Jif jars and new GIFs, aims to definitively link Jif to peanut butter and GIFs to animations, capitalizing on GIPHY's cultural relevance. This bold initiative has been praised for its humor and timely execution, coinciding with National Peanut Butter Lover’s Day.

title: What the Aflac Duck can teach marketers about taking creative risks
summary: This article explores how the Aflac Duck, after 20 years, continues to offer valuable lessons to marketers regarding experimentation, brand evolution, and achieving widespread recognition. It details the origins of the Aflac Duck campaign, a risky but successful move that significantly boosted the company's brand awareness from single digits to over 90%. The piece also highlights the principles behind Aflac's creative decisions, the duck's evolving role in marketing, and its influence on the insurance industry.

title: Kraft Heinz to boost media spending by 30% while cutting agencies
summary: Kraft Heinz plans to increase its media spending by 30% to support flagship brands while simultaneously reducing the number of creative agencies it works with from 36 to 19. This strategic shift aims to re-focus marketing efforts on its strongest brands and achieve greater efficiencies, reversing previous cost-cutting measures that led to sales declines. The company also intends to cut innovation efforts by 50% to concentrate on "fewer, bigger, bolder initiatives."

title: Colgate-Palmolive’s product portfolio gets a refresh with Tom’s of Maine expansion
summary: Colgate-Palmolive is refreshing its product portfolio, leaning on its natural brand Tom's of Maine, which recently launched its most extensive product collection in its 50-year history, featuring 16 items based on prebiotics. The expansion comes as Colgate-Palmolive seeks to elevate its products amid changing consumer preferences and improve performance in North American and European markets. Tom's of Maine will support its new product launch with its largest marketing campaign to date, focusing on paid advertising and SMS communications.

title: P&G executive to help guide Samuel Adams parent
summary: Procter & Gamble Co.'s chief product supply officer, Julio Nemeth, has been appointed to the board of the Boston Beer Co., the parent company of Samuel Adams. This move adds executive experience from a major consumer goods firm to the leadership of Boston Beer Co.

title: People Moves: Firestone Walker Promotes David Macon; Boston Beer Appoints New Board Member
summary: This article details several significant personnel changes in the beverage industry. Firestone Walker promoted David Macon to chief sales officer, recognizing his long-standing sales leadership and impact on the company's growth. The Boston Beer Company appointed Julio Nemeth, chief product supply officer for Procter & Gamble, to its board of directors, citing his extensive experience in consumer goods and manufacturing. Additionally, Heineken USA hired J. Carlos Kuri as its chief legal officer, and Alex Rodriguez made a minority investment in Presidente beer, becoming chairman of Presidente USA.

title: Oral Care Products & Other Dental Consumables Market 2020
summary: The global oral care products & other dental consumables market is projected to reach $70.46 billion by 2026, growing at a CAGR of 6.1% from 2019-2026, driven by an increase in dental diseases and demand for cosmetic dentistry. Key players like Straumann AG, Danaher, Dentsply Sirona, and 3M Company are employing various strategies including new product launches and acquisitions to expand their market footprint. The market report segments the industry by product type, distribution channel, and geography, highlighting market drivers such as rising dental disease incidence and restraints like high costs.

title: Colgate-Palmolive to Acquire Premium Oral Care Brand Hello
summary: Colgate-Palmolive is set to acquire Hello Products LLC, a premium oral care brand known for its natural ingredients and appeal to younger audiences. The acquisition, financed with cash and debt, is expected to close by February 2020, with Hello's founder and CEO remaining in leadership roles. This move expands Colgate's portfolio with a brand that offers a subscription service, diversifying revenue and reaching a new demographic.

title: Colgate to buy U.S. vegan toothpaste maker
summary: Colgate-Palmolive Co is set to acquire Hello Products LLC, a vegan toothpaste maker, to tap into the growing market of environmentally conscious consumers. Hello Products offers a range of eco-friendly and cruelty-free oral care products, aligning with the increasing demand from millennial and Gen Z consumers for sustainable options. This acquisition follows Colgate's recent launch of its own vegan-certified toothpaste, further solidifying its push into this expanding segment.

title: Baby bust: Slowing birthrates hit P&G sales
summary: Procter & Gamble Co's quarterly sales missed analyst expectations for the first time in five quarters, primarily due to weakness in baby and feminine care products, impacted by decelerating global birthrates. Despite this, P&G is investing in higher-priced premium products and innovation to boost sales, especially in markets like China where premium baby-care sales are growing. The company raised its fiscal 2020 forecast for core earnings per share growth.

title: Sysco selects new c.e.o.
summary: Sysco Corp. has appointed Kevin P. Hourican as its new president and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1, succeeding Thomas L. Bené. Hourican joins Sysco from CVS Health and will lead the food service distribution company. Additionally, Edward D. Shirley has been elected executive chair and Bradley M. Halverson as the new lead independent director.

title: Here's why stocks such as Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola are included in ESG ETFs, according to industry leaders
summary: Stocks like Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola are included in ESG ETFs despite environmental concerns because fund issuers aim to provide benchmark-like returns while reflecting values. Industry leaders from DWS Group and BlackRock explain that the goal is to offer performance and risk profiles investors are used to, requiring representation from all industries, with a focus on companies that exhibit strong ESG values within their sectors. They emphasize the need for investor education to define what ESG means and distinguish between different types of ESG investment vehicles.

title: Companies embrace invisible barcode to aid in sorting
summary: Berry Global Group is adopting Digimarc's invisible barcode technology for its plastic packaging to enhance sorting in recycling facilities. The technology, already used in various global applications, allows optical sorters to identify packaging characteristics like material composition and brand, even on challenging items, and is being advanced through the HolyGrail 2.0 project to push it into the recycling industry.

title: Documents: Procter & Gamble may resolve lawsuit over Old Spice deodorant 'injuries'
summary: Procter & Gamble is in discussions to resolve a class-action lawsuit involving over 450 plaintiffs who claim Old Spice deodorants caused chemical burns, rashes, and other skin problems. The lawsuit, initially filed in federal court and later moved to Hamilton County Common Pleas Court, alleges the company may have known about these adverse effects and continued selling the products. P&G maintains that the legal claims lack merit and that any consumer problems are skin reactions, not chemical burns, ensuring their products are safe for use by millions.

title: Colgate Debuts World's First Recyclable Toothpaste Tube Thanks to As You Sow Engagement
summary: Colgate-Palmolive Co. has launched the world's first recyclable toothpaste tube, recognized by plastics recyclers, following significant engagement from As You Sow. This initiative began with its Tom's of Maine brand and will expand to all brands over several years, addressing the issue of approximately 400 million toothpaste tubes discarded annually in the U.S. As You Sow's advocacy since 2013 led to Colgate's commitment to make all its packaging recyclable, including the breakthrough innovation for toothpaste tubes using widely recycled HDPE plastic.

title: P&G research spawns 'revolutionary packaging'
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. has commercialized its research on liquid product packaging through a licensing agreement with Innventure. This collaboration aims to bring "revolutionary packaging" to market, leveraging Innventure's expertise in launching new businesses. The initiative highlights P&G's commitment to innovation and external partnerships for commercializing its research.

title: Verizon names Carol Tomé to its board of directors
summary: Verizon has announced that Carol Tomé will join its board of directors on January 1, 2020. This marks Tomé's second major board appointment since her retirement from The Home Depot Inc. on August 31. The article also lists related board appointments at other companies.

title: Elisa rolls-out industrial IoT to 100 P&G factories, says ‘world will change’ with 5G
summary: Finnish telecoms company Elisa is expanding its industrial IoT monitoring and insights solution to 100 Procter & Gamble factories, building on an initial rollout at 10 sites. Elisa emphasizes the transformative potential of 5G in industrial settings, beyond just speed, by enabling streaming analytics at the network edge. The company offers its data-analytics and digital-twinning recipe to third parties, leveraging its own successful internal digital transformation.

title: HUL, Colgate-Palmolive vs ITC, Dabur India: Which type of FMCG stocks are shining?
summary: Shares of foreign promoter-owned FMCG companies have outperformed their domestic counterparts in 2019, with the former posting an average gain of 18.9% while the latter saw negative returns. This disparity is attributed to factors like promoter holding, dividend payouts, and investor sentiment regarding business strategies. The slowdown in rural and urban demand, coupled with muted volume growth and an unexpected lack of benefit from corporate tax cuts for Indian FMCGs, further highlights the divide.

title: P&G, Reese Witherspoon’s media brand develop content around bestseller ‘Fair Play’
summary: Procter & Gamble has partnered with Reese Witherspoon's media company, Hello Sunshine, to create content around Eve Rodsky's bestselling book "Fair Play." This collaboration includes a video series and podcast called "In All Fairness," distributed via YouTube and social media, aimed at addressing the imbalance of domestic workload. P&G is leveraging this partnership to move beyond traditional advertising and promote gender equality, aligning with its broader efforts in social initiatives.

title: The Power Of Purpose: How Sam Latif And P&G Are Innovating To Serve The 1.7 Billion People With Disabilities Market
summary: This article highlights Sam Latif, Procter and Gamble's Company Accessibility Leader, and her efforts to drive innovation catering to the 1.7 billion people with disabilities market. Latif, who is blind, has spearheaded product design changes, inclusive advertising, and internal workshops to make P&G's offerings more accessible and relevant to this significant consumer segment. Her work emphasizes that serving people with disabilities is not only a moral obligation but also a substantial business opportunity, leading to increased consumer base and employee engagement.

title: Procter & Gamble Embraces Continuous Planning and Execution
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has adopted a continuous planning and execution approach for its supply chain, leveraging Kinaxis' RapidResponse platform. This allows them to adjust demand and supply multiple times a day for some products, significantly improving responsiveness to market changes and incremental business requests. The strategy also focuses on developing skilled "citizen developers" and has led to a more agile and efficient supply chain, as demonstrated by their effective hurricane response.

title: Factbox: Meet McDonald's new CEO: Chris Kempczinski
summary: Chris Kempczinski has replaced Steve Easterbrook as CEO of McDonald's Corp after Easterbrook's dismissal due to a consensual relationship with an employee. Kempczinski, 51, joined McDonald's in 2015 as executive vice president and previously held roles at Procter & Gamble Co, PepsiCo Inc, and Kraft Foods. He holds an MBA from Harvard Business School and a bachelor's degree from Duke University, and was responsible for McDonald's U.S. operations before his promotion to CEO.

title: Procter & Gamble earnings and sales top estimates, sending shares higher
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) reported strong fiscal first-quarter earnings and sales that exceeded analyst expectations, leading the company to raise its sales and earnings outlook for the year. The consumer giant's growth was driven by innovation, marketing, and a streamlined organizational structure, with notable performance in its beauty, health care, and fabric and home care lines. Shares of P&G rose significantly on the news, as the company continues to focus on creating new businesses and products rather than just taking market share.

title: Shampoo Giants Unilever and Procter & Gamble Go Head to Head
summary: Unilever and Procter & Gamble are engaged in a price war in the U.S. shampoo market as Unilever aims to gain market share. This competition has impacted Unilever's third-quarter sales, with underlying sales growth at 2.9%, below analyst forecasts. Despite raising prices in other markets, Unilever's CFO Graeme Pitkethly noted that the rivalry with P&G has capped price increases in North America.

title: Fountain Square, Fifth Third Center renovations to be completed in 2021
summary: Renovations to Fountain Square and the Fifth Third Center in Cincinnati are expected to be completed in 2021. The Fifth Third Center will feature a new two-story lobby, expanded retail space, and a new financial center, designed with security in mind after a 2018 shooting. Fountain Square will also receive a permanent stage to replace the temporary one, improving programming and performer accommodations.

title: What Side of History Will Procter & Gamble Be On?
summary: The NRDC is campaigning against Procter & Gamble for its continued use of 100% virgin forest fiber, sourced from climate-critical forests like the Canadian boreal, for its tissue products. Activists and organizations pressured P&G at its annual shareholder meeting to adopt more sustainable sourcing policies and stop contributing to deforestation. The article highlights the environmental impact of P&G's practices and calls on the company to take responsibility and make changes.

title: Protesters gather outside Procter & Gamble to demand changes
summary: Protesters from the Natural Resources Defense Council gathered outside Procter & Gamble's headquarters to demand a change in how the company makes toilet paper, citing concerns about deforestation in the Canadian boreal forest and endangering species. They advocate for alternatives like bamboo, hemp, or recycled paper. Procter & Gamble responded by highlighting its investments in sustainability, including FSC and Rainforest Alliance certifications for Charmin, and a partnership with the Arbor Day Foundation to plant trees.

title: Chainsaw-wielding bear, others protest outside Procter and Gamble’s shareholder meeting
summary: Environmental activists, including a protester dressed as a chainsaw-wielding bear, demonstrated outside Procter & Gamble's annual shareholder meeting in Cincinnati. They criticized P&G for using virgin timber from the Canadian boreal forest for Charmin toilet paper, advocating for sustainable tissue products. While P&G reported strong financial results, shareholder concerns about sustainability were raised, prompting the company to address its efforts in reforestation and caribou protection, though it defended its use of virgin paper for product quality.

title: Why Has Procter & Gamble’s Stock Grown 1.5x In The Past Year?
summary: Procter & Gamble's stock has risen 1.5x in the past year, from $81.91 to $123, despite relatively flat revenues and a modest increase in net margins. This growth is primarily attributed to a 39% increase in its P/E multiple. The article details how revenue growth, improved net margins, and a higher P/E multiple — compared to competitors like Colgate Palmolive and Unilever — have driven this stock performance.

title: Why is there a giant toilet paper roll outside P&G?
summary: Environmental protesters rallied outside Procter & Gamble's headquarters during its annual meeting, bringing a giant toilet paper roll to highlight concerns about the company's use of virgin paper and its impact on Canadian forests. Inside, CEO David Taylor addressed shareholders, noting a significant increase in P&G's stock price. Hedge fund investor Nelson Peltz, who was re-elected to the board, has seen a $1.7 billion profit on his stake in the company.

title: P&G: Will the company split its stock?
summary: Procter & Gamble's shares are nearing an all-time high, prompting speculation about a stock split, which the company has done six times since 1970 when prices climbed above $100. Local analysts are divided on the likelihood and benefits of such a split, with some pointing to P&G's history and investor sentiment, while others note the changing landscape of stock accessibility and the dwindling number of splits among large companies.

title: Clorox will attach environmental, animal-testing goals to executive compensation
summary: Clorox Co. announced new goals for reducing plastic, lowering emissions, and avoiding animal testing, which will be tied to the compensation of its chairman and chief executive. This decision follows similar moves by oil companies like Royal Dutch Shell PLC and BP PLC. While Clorox declined to specify compensation terms, it stated that achieving these goals could lead to executive bonuses.

title: Nestlé, P&G won’t meet 2020 deforestation goals
summary: Nestlé and Procter & Gamble are set to miss their 2020 goals for eliminating deforestation from their supply chains, according to recent reports. This failure highlights the difficulties in achieving transparency in palm oil supply chains and raises questions about the effectiveness of certification as the sole solution. Environmental groups and even some food companies had previously warned that corporations would struggle to meet these ambitious targets.

title: Nestle, P&G say they will miss 2020 deforestation goals
summary: Nestle SA and Procter & Gamble Co have acknowledged they will not meet their 2020 goals to source ingredients that do not contribute to deforestation. Both companies, who made these pledges in 2010 at the urging of the Consumer Goods Forum, cite underestimation of demand and lax government regulations as reasons for falling short. Other major consumer goods companies have either declined to provide specifics on their deforestation goals or stated they will not make the 2020 zero deforestation pledges.

title: Former P&G executive to help guide big data firm
summary: Former Procter & Gamble vice chairman Dimitri Panayotopoulos has joined the board of IRI, a global firm specializing in big data, predictive analytics, and insights for consumer, retail, and media companies. Panayotopoulos will help guide the big data firm with his extensive experience from P&G.

title: Going Beyond the Tampon, Big Brands Try New Ideas
summary: Major feminine-care brands like Kimberly-Clark and P&G are investing in innovative alternatives to traditional tampons and pads, driven by consumer demand for sustainable and chemical-minimizing products. Kimberly-Clark has invested $25 million in Thinx, a maker of reusable "period proof underwear," while P&G launched a Tampax menstrual cup. This signals a shift in a market that has seen little change for over half a century, addressing a growing interest in new feminine hygiene solutions.

title: 79 jobs expected to shift at P&G facilities under new subcontractor
summary: 79 jobs associated with facilities support at Procter & Gamble (P&G) locations in Southwest Ohio are expected to shift as Eurest Services' contract with Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL) ends. While local entities were informed of a "plant closing," Eurest clarifies it is not closing facilities or eliminating jobs, but rather transitioning contracts. Personnel will either be retained by Eurest and repositioned or transitioned to the new support services contractor.
source: Hamilton In-depth, Investigative News from Journal-News
source_domain: Hamilton In-depth, Investigative News from Journal-News

title: P&G: Consumer giant's ads are getting political. Will that draw backlash?
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has increasingly incorporated socially-conscious messages into its advertising, a strategy some critics argue politicizes its products. While P&G states this approach aligns with evolving consumer expectations for brands to "stand for something," it has also faced backlash, particularly for ads like Gillette's "toxic masculinity" campaign, raising questions about whether such marketing risks alienating consumers. The company, however, maintains that its focus on "equality" is a winning formula, with executives noting increased brand affinity and long-term loyalty among consumers who appreciate a company's values.

title: APR gives recyclability thumbs up to PP additive
summary: The Association of Plastic Recyclers (APR) has confirmed that Milliken's Millad NX 8000 PP clarifier line meets or exceeds its guidance for recycling-friendly products. This additive, which accounts for 80% of the world's clarified PP market, was found not to complicate the plastics recycling process or harm the finished product after extensive testing. The NX 8000 improves PP clarity and offers benefits to molders by reducing temperatures and cycle times, leading to cost savings.

title: PureCycle, Aptar partner to produce recycled polypropylene resin
summary: AptarGroup has partnered with PureCycle Technologies LLC to introduce PureCycle's Ultra-Pure Recycled Polypropylene (UPRP) into dispensing applications. PureCycle's process transforms plastic feedstock into UPRP resin with virgin-like properties, closing the loop in plastics reuse and making recycled plastics more accessible. Aptar will collaborate with PureCycle on the transformation process and prepare for food-grade requirements in Europe, while PureCycle plans to build its first plant in Ohio to produce 100 million pounds of UPRP per year starting in 2021.

title: Church & Dwight: An Example of the American Valuation Premium
summary: This article examines the high valuation of U.S. consumer staple stocks, using Church & Dwight (CHD) as a prime example, and compares them to their European counterparts like Unilever, noting an "S&P 500 index premium" in the U.S. Despite Church & Dwight's strong brand portfolio and historical outperformance, the author expresses caution due to its current elevated valuation metrics relative to historical averages and discusses potential forward return scenarios. The article suggests that while consumer staples are defensive, their current valuations are stretched, leading the author to keep CHD on a watchlist rather than investing new money.

title: Oral Care: Comparative Market Share Analysis, Know Who’s
authors: HTF Market Intelligence Consulting Pvt. Ltd.
summary: This press release announces a new research study by HTF MI providing a comprehensive analysis of the Global and China Oral Care Market. The study covers historical progress, ongoing market scenarios, future prospects, and detailed data on leading companies, products, strategies, and market shares. It also examines market dynamics, key growth drivers, challenges, and regional segmentation with a forecast up to 2025.

title: 3M’s chief sustainability officer, Gayle Schueller, on how her company is embracing the circular economy
summary: Gayle Schueller, 3M’s chief sustainability officer, discusses the company's commitment to waste prevention, recycling, and overall environmental sustainability. 3M aims to integrate sustainability into its product development to reduce environmental impact and avoid past mistakes related to chemical persistence. The company's efforts include using recycled materials in products like Scotch-Brite sponges and Thinsulate insulation, and developing smog-reducing roofing granules.

title: Procter & Gamble Stock: What’s behind Its Solid Return?
summary: The article discusses Procter & Gamble's strong stock performance, highlighting a 29.7% year-to-date return driven by robust organic sales, share buybacks, and a healthy dividend yield. It attributes this success to consistent growth in organic sales, impressive profit margins, and a focus on premium innovation, even as other consumer staples like Kimberly-Clark, Colgate-Palmolive, and Church & Dwight also show solid returns. The outlook for P&G remains positive, with continued organic sales growth and margin expansion expected to support the stock.

title: Procter & Gamble celebrates 50 years at Alexandria plant
summary: The Procter & Gamble plant in Alexandria, Louisiana, celebrated its 50th anniversary, recognized by CEO David Taylor as a "world-class manufacturing facility." The plant plays a vital role in producing laundry products for a third of the U.S. and is an economic engine and community pillar, according to Pineville Mayor Clarence Fields. The company has invested millions into the facility, promising future growth.

title: P&G executives: Best still to come at Alexandria plant
summary: Procter & Gamble executives, including CEO David Taylor, visited their Pineville plant to celebrate its 50th anniversary. They expressed strong optimism for the plant's future growth and its critical role in the company's North American fabric care business, despite its already significant achievements. The facility, which started producing dry laundry detergent in 1969, now employs about 600 people and has expanded its product offerings to include Tide Pods.

title: Hasbro will phase out plastics from packaging — but not toys
summary: Hasbro Inc. announced plans to phase out plastic from its product packaging, including elastic bands and shrink wrap, starting in 2020 with a goal to virtually eliminate plastic from new product packaging by the end of 2022. While this initiative addresses consumer backlash against single-use plastics in packaging, the company has not yet committed to reducing plastic usage in the toys themselves. Chief Operating Officer John Frascotti indicated that plans for more sustainable materials in toys would be announced soon, though some packaging, like for Easy Bake Oven ingredients, will retain plastic due to health and regulatory requirements.

title: 'Icon' Procter & Gamble celebrates 50 years in Cenla
summary: Procter & Gamble's Pineville plant is celebrating 50 years of operation, evolving from 150 employees making dry laundry detergent to approximately 600 employees producing a diverse range of products with a payroll of over $60 million. The plant is considered an economic icon in Central Louisiana, not only for its direct employment and payroll but also for its ripple effect on local infrastructure, supporting ancillary businesses, and community involvement. Local leaders credit P&G with driving significant economic growth and providing stable, well-paying jobs, making it a critical fixture in the region.

title: Report: Chipotle, Sweetgreen bowls contain cancer-linked ‘forever chemicals’
summary: A report from The New Food Economy found that molded fiber bowls from restaurants like Chipotle and Sweetgreen contain cancer-linked "forever chemicals" called PFAS. While the levels don't exceed FDA thresholds and no immediate health threat is suggested for consumers, these chemicals do not biodegrade and can accumulate in the environment and potentially migrate into food. This raises concerns for environmental sustainability and long-term health, despite these bowls often being advertised as compostable.

title: P&G posts strong sales, takes $8 bln Gillette writedown
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. reported strong quarterly revenue and adjusted profit, beating Wall Street expectations and sending shares to a record high. Despite the positive performance, the company took an $8 billion non-cash writedown on its Gillette shaving business due to currency fluctuations, increased competition, and a shrinking market for razors as consumers shave less frequently. The writedown primarily reflects challenges in the grooming segment, while other categories like beauty and home care showed significant organic sales growth.

title: Procter & Gamble shares jump on earnings beat, optimistic 2020 outlook despite Gillette write-down
summary: Procter & Gamble reported stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and revenue, leading to a jump in share price, despite an $8 billion write-down of its Gillette brand. The company offered an optimistic forecast for fiscal 2020, projecting revenue growth of 3% to 4% and adjusted EPS growth of 4% to 9%. This performance was driven by strong organic sales growth, particularly in health care and fabric/home care segments, and strategic price increases.

title: P&G posts strong sales, takes $8 billion Gillette writedown
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) reported strong quarterly revenue and adjusted profit, beating Wall Street expectations, despite taking an $8 billion non-cash writedown on its Gillette shaving business. The writedown is attributed to currency fluctuations, increased competition, and a shrinking market for razors as consumers shave less frequently. P&G's shares rose significantly after the strong earnings report, driven by organic sales growth across its beauty and fabric/home care units.

title: P&G Posts Strong Sales Even as It Raises Prices
summary: Procter & Gamble reported its highest quarterly sales growth in over a decade, driven by strong consumer spending on household staples despite price increases. However, the company also incurred an $8 billion charge to write down the value of its Gillette razor business, highlighting challenges faced by big brands from changing consumer habits and new online competitors. P&G's shares rose following the strong sales report.

title: Procter & Gamble continues growth streak with year-end results
summary: Procter & Gamble reported strong year-end results, exceeding analyst expectations with its best sales-growth numbers in over a decade. Despite an $8 billion accounting charge related to the Gillette brand's declining value, the company reported core earnings per share of $1.10 and 7 percent organic sales growth. P&G attributes its resurgence to a 2014 strategy of divesting brands and investing in premium products.

title: P&G up to 1,100 employees — and growing
summary: Procter & Gamble's Tabler Station plant in Berkeley County, W.Va., now employs about 1,100 people and aims to fill 275 more positions. The plant, which produces products like Dawn and Swiffer, expects all operations to be functional by the end of 2020. This expansion is part of P&G's broader North American supply chain transformation, involving over $500 million in investment.

title: Procter & Gamble Class Action Says Costco Rebates Aren’t Delivered
summary: A class action lawsuit has been filed against Procter & Gamble (P&G) alleging that the company failed to deliver $25 rebates promised to consumers who purchased $100 worth of P&G products at Costco. The plaintiff claims P&G did not fulfill its obligations, stating the program ended and directing inquiries to Costco, despite consumers meeting the promotion's terms. The lawsuit alleges breach of contract, violation of consumer sales practices acts, and unjust enrichment, seeking redress for all U.S. persons who participated and did not receive their rebate.

title: The potential of polypropylene
summary: The article explores the growing potential for recycling polypropylene (PP), driven by technological advancements, increased demand from global brands for recycled materials, and heightened consumer awareness of plastic waste. Companies like Envision Plastics, St. Joseph Plastics, and PureCycle Technologies are spearheading efforts to innovate PP recycling processes and expand the market for postconsumer recycled (PCR) PP. Despite challenges in collection, standardization, and pricing, reprocessors see significant future growth, with PureCycle Technologies notably preselling its recycled PP output for the next two decades.

title: Donald Knauss, Richard Smucker Honored by Grocery Manufacturers Assoc.
summary: Donald Knauss and Richard Smucker are being honored with the 2019 Hall of Achievement Award by the Grocery Manufacturers Association (GMA) for their significant contributions to the consumer packaged goods industry. Knauss previously served as chair and CEO of The Clorox Company, while Smucker was the CEO and co-CEO of The J.M. Smucker Company. The award will be presented at GMA’s annual Leadership Forum on August 15th.

title: Milacron acquired by another local public company for $2B
summary: Milacron Holdings Corp., a Cincinnati-based public company, announced its acquisition for $2 billion by another Greater Cincinnati public company. Tom Goeke is the CEO of Milacron, which is a plastics processing company based in Blue Ash. This significant transaction involves two local public entities.

title: Procter & Gamble launches hair care line for black women
summary: Procter & Gamble's My Black is Beautiful platform has launched a new hair care line specifically for Black women, available exclusively at Sally Beauty stores and online. The line, inspired by an online community of 2.6 million women, was developed in partnership with Sally Beauty and P&G's technical expertise in textured hair. It includes shampoo, conditioner, conditioning creams, and an intense recovery treatment designed to nourish, moisturize, and renew curly hair.

title: Goldman upgrades Procter & Gamble, predicting a 'double-digit' return
summary: Goldman Sachs upgraded Procter & Gamble to "buy" from "neutral," predicting a potential "double-digit return" for shareholders. The firm raised its target price to $125 from $114, citing P&G's benefit from accelerated end-market growth and an expected increase in organic volume and profit dollar growth. Despite past concerns about growth and trade war effects, P&G shares were up, continuing a yearly trend of over 20% growth.

title: Howard Hughes Corp hires Centerview Partners to explore alternatives, including a sale: Sources
summary: Howard Hughes Corp. has hired Centerview Partners to explore strategic alternatives, including a potential sale of the company, due to its struggling stock performance over the past three years. Chairman Bill Ackman supports the review, which also includes exploring joint ventures or spinoffs, with the goal of completion by the end of summer. The company later confirmed the strategic review, leading to a significant jump in its shares.

title: Estée Lauder CEO Fabrizio Freda on Makeup Trends and Chinese Millennials
summary: Estée Lauder CEO Fabrizio Freda discusses the company's strategy for growth in emerging markets, particularly China, and how they navigate trade conflicts. He highlights the differences in spending habits and attitudes between Chinese and U.S. millennials, emphasizing the importance of "glocal" strategies and continuous transformation to capture opportunities in a volatile market. Freda also touches on the company's acquisition strategy and the emerging trend of personalization in the beauty industry.

title: Alibaba and JD.Com to Combine Facial Recognition With Data in Bid for Merchant Loyalty
summary: Alibaba and JD.com are integrating facial recognition and deep customer data to enhance merchant loyalty and diversify revenue streams amidst slowing e-commerce growth in China. This "new retail" approach offers personalized marketing and operational efficiencies, benefiting brands like Bestore and Nestle, while raising questions about data management and retailer dependency.

title: Former PepsiCo CIO Robert Dixon Named To The Okta Board of Directors
summary: Okta, Inc. has announced the appointment of Robert Dixon, former Senior Vice President and Global CIO of PepsiCo, Inc., to its board of directors, effective June 14. Dixon brings extensive experience from PepsiCo and Procter & Gamble, as well as current board positions with Anthem, Inc. and Build-A-Bear Workshop, Inc.
