His expertise in digital transformation and IT infrastructure is expected to provide invaluable insight for Okta's vision of enabling organizations to leverage technology effectively.

title: P&G and Tokyo 2020 create first-ever medal podiums made entirely of recycled plastic for upcoming Olympic Games
summary: P&G and Tokyo 2020 are collaborating to create the first-ever Olympic medal podiums made entirely from recycled plastic for the upcoming Olympic Games. This initiative involves collecting plastic from the public and oceans, contributing to sustainability goals and raising awareness about plastic waste. The project aligns with broader Olympic Movement efforts to embed sustainability principles and highlights how the Games can inspire environmental action.

title: Vans Owner VF Corp. Taps Tmall to Bolster China Offering
summary: VF Corp., parent company of brands like Vans, The North Face, and Timberland, is expanding its collaboration with Alibaba's Tmall to enhance its reach and sales to Chinese consumers. Tmall will utilize data-driven initiatives to help VF Corp. target buyers, identify growth opportunities, and tailor products for the Chinese market. This partnership builds on previous successful collaborations, including product launches informed by the Tmall Innovation Center.

title: 3M Deconsolidates Venezuelan Subsidiary
summary: 3M has deconsolidated its Venezuelan subsidiary, citing an "unstable environment and heightened unrest" and expecting a $160 million charge in the second quarter, although the move is not expected to cause economic impact to 3M. This follows similar actions by other Minnesota companies like Ecolab and major corporations such as Colgate-Palmolive and PepsiCo due to Venezuela's unstable economic conditions.

title: Former P&G vice president tapped as managing partner by private equity firm
summary: Luigi Feola, a 21-year veteran and former general manager for global luxury brands at Procter & Gamble, has been appointed as a managing partner for the world's largest consumer-focused private equity firm. This move signifies a significant career transition for Feola from a major consumer goods corporation to a leadership role in private equity.

title: Building a Simple, Low Cost Indexed ETF Portfolio in USD
summary: This article discusses the advantages of building a low-cost, indexed ETF portfolio using USD-denominated ETFs, primarily to reduce withholding taxes in registered accounts like RRSPs. It explains the concept of withholding taxes on ETFs, strategies to efficiently convert CAD to USD using Norbert's Gambit, and outlines several USD ETF portfolio options with significantly lower total MERs compared to their CAD counterparts. The author emphasizes the potential savings, especially for larger portfolios, despite the initial effort involved in currency conversion and managing US-listed ETFs.

title: How P&G created a ‘ready for anything’ supply chain
summary: Procter & Gamble has transformed its disaster response from reactive to proactive over the last decade by centralizing decision-making and implementing advanced technology. The company now uses Kinaxis's Rapid Response software, which integrates P&G's supply chain data with external information like weather forecasts, allowing for quick scenario planning and pre-emptive adjustments to avoid disruptions. This strategic shift enabled P&G to maintain consistent supply during events like Hurricane Harvey, when competitors struggled.

title: Intuit Acquires Data Analytics Startup Origami Logic
summary: Intuit Inc. has announced its agreement to acquire Silicon Valley-based data analytics startup Origami Logic Inc. for an undisclosed amount, expected to close in Q4 2019. Founded in 2011, Origami Logic provides market performance analytics to major brands and has raised $64.5 million in total funding. This acquisition aims to enhance Intuit's ability to deliver personalized insights to its customers.

title: Loop’s ‘waste-free’ e-commerce platform launches with P&G, Kroger, Walgreens on board
summary: Loop, TerraCycle's "circular shopping platform," has launched its e-commerce site with Kroger and Walgreens as founding retail partners. The platform offers multi-use packaging for products from brands like Unilever, Mars, Nestle, PepsiCo, Colgate-Palmolive, and Procter & Gamble, aimed at significantly reducing waste. The pilot program, currently available in limited U.S. and Paris locations, requires a deposit for packaging that is returned, cleaned, refilled, and resold, emphasizing the companies' commitment to testing and scaling sustainable consumer solutions.

title: Colgate-Palmolive tops Gartner’s 2019 Supply Chain rankings
summary: Colgate-Palmolive has secured the top position in Gartner’s 2019 Supply Chain Top 25 rankings, moving up from fourth place in 2018 due to strong financial performance and focus on corporate social responsibility. Alibaba and Akzo Nobel also made their debut on the shortlist. Unilever joined the "Masters" category after consistently ranking in the top five for seven consecutive years, recognized for its advanced digital supply chain processes and use of emerging technologies.

title: What the Harry’s acquisition means for retailers
summary: The acquisition of direct-to-consumer brand Harry's by Edgewell Personal Care highlights a broader trend of consumer product giants buying startups to gain direct customer connections and data. This shift presents both challenges and opportunities for traditional retailers, who must adapt by partnering with niche brands or developing their own private labels to remain competitive against CPGs that are now building their own direct marketing capabilities. While some see this as a defensive move by CPGs, others believe it could streamline operations for retailers by consolidating brand management.

title: P&G unveils its largest R&D center in the world. It's in Mason, Ohio.
summary: Procter & Gamble has unveiled its new and expanded Mason Business Center, which is now the company's largest research & development center globally. P&G invested $400 million in the expansion, bringing the facility to 2 million square feet and accommodating 2,800 workers, including those from its consolidated Sharon Woods innovation center. This move aims to boost efficiency after years of corporate restructuring and divestitures.

title: Morgan Stanley upgrades Coca-Cola to overweight: 'Coke is now our top mega-cap staples pick'
summary: Morgan Stanley upgraded Coca-Cola shares to overweight from equal weight, setting a new 12-month price target of $55. The firm believes Coca-Cola is trading at an "unfair discount to peers" given its superior growth outlook, pricing power, and rebounding emerging market trends. Coca-Cola is now Morgan Stanley's top mega-cap staples pick, with analysts raising future EPS estimates.

title: P&G Union center near Dayton airport sold for $93 million
summary: The Procter & Gamble distribution center in Union, Ohio, near the Dayton airport, was sold for over $93 million to ILPT Properties LLC. P&G, which operates as a tenant, stated that the sale will not impact its business operations, lease, or employee numbers. The facility, strategically located for logistics, was acquired from ARCP ID Union OH, with ILPT Properties focusing on e-commerce-driven industrial and logistics real estate.

title: Razor startup Harry’s will be acquired by Edgewell Personal Care for $1.37B
summary: Edgewell Personal Care is set to acquire razor startup Harry's for $1.37 billion, expanding its portfolio of direct-to-consumer brands. Harry's co-founders will become co-presidents of U.S. operations for Edgewell following the acquisition. The deal, which involves 79% cash and 21% stock, is expected to close by the end of the first quarter of 2020.

title: Shaving upstart Harry's is selling for $1.37 billion to the company that owns Schick razors
summary: Edgewell Personal Care, owner of Schick and Wilkinson razor brands, announced its plan to acquire U.S.-based shaving startup Harry's for $1.37 billion in a cash-and-stock deal. This acquisition aims to expand Edgewell's presence in the rapidly growing U.S. grooming market, with Harry's founders Andy Katz-Mayfield and Jeff Raider joining Edgewell's executive team. The deal makes Harry's the latest shaving startup bought by a larger rival, highlighting the increasing focus on the men's grooming industry.

title: Shaving Start-Up Harry’s Will Be Sold to Owner of Schick for $1.37 Billion (Published 2019)
summary: Harry's, a shaving start-up, is being acquired by Edgewell Personal Care, the owner of Schick and Wilkinson razor brands, for approximately $1.37 billion in stock and cash. This deal highlights a trend of established companies purchasing younger, internet-born competitors, similar to Unilever's acquisition of Dollar Shave Club. Post-acquisition, Harry's founders, Andy Katz-Mayfield and Jeff Raider, will manage Edgewell's U.S. operations, aiming to strengthen their position as a distant second to Procter & Gamble's Gillette in the men's shaving market.

title: Living Legacies Series: Meet Paul Sagel, Co-Creator of Crest Whitestrips
summary: Paul Sagel, co-creator of Crest Whitestrips, shares his 26-year journey at P&G, detailing the product's innovative development and profound impact on consumers. He discusses the early challenges, the pivotal moment of pitching the idea to the CTO, and his continued passion for innovation at P&G today. Sagel emphasizes the importance of improving lives through superior products and highlights the rapid pace of modern innovation.

title: Procter & Gamble Strength is Feeding Gains for 'XLP' ETF
summary: The article discusses how Procter & Gamble's strong performance is significantly contributing to the gains of the Consumer Staples Select SPDR (XLP) ETF. Despite the stock being largely established, its recent growth, including a 40% rise over the past year, has buoyed the ETF, which has a 15% allocation to P&G. Analysts suggest P&G's stock is breaking out above a long-term trendline, indicating a higher trajectory.

title: Misconduct at Kraft Heinz puts spotlight on employee pressure to meet bonus targets
summary: Kraft Heinz announced it will restate its financial statements for 2016 and 2017 by $181 million due to employee misconduct in procurement, resulting in reprimands for about a dozen employees. This incident has raised questions about the company's internal controls and its bonus structure, which heavily ties employee compensation to annual targets. Critics suggest that aggressive cost-cutting targets and rapid promotions of inexperienced staff may have contributed to a culture susceptible to such misconduct.

title: P&G renames Merck Limited as Procter & Gamble Health Ltd
summary: Procter & Gamble has renamed Merck Ltd in India as Procter & Gamble Health Limited, following its global acquisition of Merck KGaA's consumer health business. The name change was approved by the Registrar of Companies, effective May 6th. This move signifies P&G's strategy to leverage its combined expertise and strong brand portfolio in India's growing consumer health market.

title: What Makes A CSR Message Resonate With Millennials And Generation-Z?
summary: This article explores how Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) messages resonate with Millennial and Generation-Z consumers. It highlights that while young consumers expect companies to be socially responsible, authenticity, commitment, and alignment between the company and the cause are crucial for effective CSR campaigns. The piece also notes that many young consumers are price-conscious and may not pay a premium for CSR efforts, though such initiatives can influence brand preference at similar price points.

title: P&G veteran tapped as president of Ulta Beauty
summary: Dave Kimbell, a former brand manager at Procter & Gamble, has been appointed president of Ulta Beauty Inc., the largest U.S. beauty retailer. This move brings a P&G veteran into a top leadership role at a major beauty company.

title: Earnings preview: What to look for when Procter & Gamble reports Q3 results
summary: Procter & Gamble (PG) is set to report its Q3 2019 earnings on April 23, with analysts expecting a 4% EPS increase and a slight revenue bump. The company has consistently beaten earnings estimates, despite facing challenges from changing retail trends, high costs, and currency fluctuations. P&G's diverse product portfolio, brand loyalty, and strategic acquisitions are expected to support its performance and margins.

title: Procter & Gamble plant in Albany named Manufacturer of Year
summary: The Procter & Gamble plant in Albany was named Georgia's 2019 Manufacturer of the Year in the large manufacturer category by Gov. Brian Kemp. The plant, which employs over 500 people and has been in the community for more than 45 years, was recognized for its economic impact, community involvement, corporate responsibility, and commitment to workforce development. P&G's Albany plant produces paper towels and tissue paper, contributes significantly to the local and state economy, and actively participates in community organizations.

title: Wisconsin carrier recognized by Procter & Gamble
summary: Contract Transport Services (CTS), a Green Bay, Wisconsin-based carrier, received two "Carrier of the Year" awards from Procter & Gamble for Best Customer Service On-Time and Best Tender Service. This recognition highlights CTS's exceptional service, innovation, responsiveness, and strong partnership with P&G, marking the first time the company has earned such honors. CTS President Curt Reitz attributed the awards to the dedication of their drivers and staff who consistently go above and beyond.

title: Why Coty Stock Lost 67% Last Year
summary: Coty's stock dropped 67% last year due to struggles absorbing the Cover Girl acquisition, executive upheaval, and weaker-than-expected guidance from supply-chain disruptions. Despite some short-lived gains and new leadership appointments, investors lost faith in the company's turnaround potential. The company hopes new CEO Pierre Laubies can execute a turnaround to recoup some losses, with new leadership aiming to shore up pain points.

title: Big Firms Can't Innovate: How P&G Ventures Is Dispelling The Myth
summary: This article discusses how P&G Ventures, a new division within Procter and Gamble, is challenging the notion that large corporations cannot innovate. Leigh Radford, VP and GM of P&G Ventures, explains how the initiative operates like a startup studio to create new brands and businesses, focusing on direct-to-consumer models and fostering a lean, agile environment within the large company structure. The division aims to solve consumer problems in categories new to P&G and adapt to the changing landscape of brand discovery.

title: P&G social media post featuring plus-size model makes waves
summary: A social media post by Procter & Gamble featuring a plus-size model for its Venus razors sparked thousands of responses, including critical ones. Although the model, Anna O’Brien, was not paid for the endorsement, P&G requested to share her photo on the brand's Twitter account. The post generated significant engagement and discussion online.

title: FTI Consulting adds Rodolfo Araujo as senior managing director in Washington, DC
summary: FTI Consulting has appointed Rodolfo Araujo as a senior managing director in its strategic communications segment in Washington, D.C. Araujo, an expert in corporate governance, proxy contests, and M&A, will lead the Americas corporate governance and activism offering and join the firm's activism and M&A solutions practice. He brings nearly a decade of experience from Institutional Shareholder Solutions (ISS) and Sands Capital, where he specialized in analyzing equity markets and advising on high-profile corporate events for major clients.

title: Former P&G executive joins C-suite of pharma firm
summary: Dr. Andreas Grauer, a former Procter & Gamble Co. executive, has been appointed as the chief medical officer of Corcept Therapeutics Inc. Corcept Therapeutics is a pharmaceutical company focused on discovering and developing drugs for metabolic, oncologic, and psychiatric disorders. This move strengthens Corcept Therapeutics' leadership team with Grauer's extensive experience.

title: P&G sets world record for longest TV commercial
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. set a Guinness World Record for the longest TV commercial ever by airing a 14-hour version of an Old Spice ad. The commercial was composed of hundreds of short clips edited together. This achievement was officially recognized by Guinness World Records.

title: How To Land A Full-Time Gig At P&G
summary: This article details Payton Lang's journey from intern to full-time employee at Procter & Gamble, highlighting her application process, internship experience, and advice for students. Lang, a Washington University in St. Louis Olin Business School graduate, shares insights on securing a position with the global company, emphasizing preparation, networking, and authenticity.

title: Update: P&G moving around employees to take bite from 500 employee cut in 2020
summary: Procter & Gamble is moving employees around to mitigate job losses from a previously announced cut of 500 positions as production shifts from Iowa City to West Virginia by 2020. The company is working with the factory's union, hiring locally for other positions, and moving some employees to different facilities to lessen the impact. While hair care and body wash production are moving, oral rinse manufacturing will remain, and toothbrush employees will not be affected.

title: Denver Company Pays $4.2M for Former Procter & Gamble Plant
summary: A Denver-based real estate investment company, IPT Avenel DC Urban Renewal, LLC (registered out of the same address as Black Creek Group), purchased a former Procter & Gamble plant in Woodbridge, Middlesex County for over $4.2 million in November. The P&G facility, which manufactured fragrances and chemicals for Tide detergent, had been shuttered the previous year, leading to the transfer of production to an Ohio plant. The new owner's plans for the property, located at 100 Essex Avenue East, are currently unknown.

title: Procter & Gamble face Israeli class-action lawsuit regarding Oral B mouthwash labelling
summary: Procter & Gamble is facing an Israeli class-action lawsuit seeking $8.3 million over the labeling of its Oral B and Pro Expert mouthwashes. The lawsuit alleges that the Hebrew instructions encourage excessive use compared to the English instructions, leading to higher repeat purchases. The Tel Aviv District Court approved the class-action status, stating P&G failed to adequately inform consumers of both usage options.

title: Will P&G stock split again soon?
summary: Procter & Gamble's stock is approaching all-time highs, prompting speculation about a potential stock split, a question not asked by investors in 15 years. Historically, P&G has split its stock two-for-one when shares trade above $100 for an extended period, leading to anticipation among investors. The article explores past precedents for splits and delves into why one might not have happened in other instances where the stock briefly crossed the $100 mark.

title: Procter & Gamble job fair set for Feb. 27 in Hagerstown
summary: Procter & Gamble will host an open house and job fair on Feb. 27 from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. at the Fletcher Branch of the Washington County Free Library in Hagerstown, seeking to hire additional plant technicians for its Tabler Station manufacturing facility near Martinsburg, W.Va. The company aims to hire over 450 people in the next 18 months, particularly for shampoo and conditioner production, and plans to produce a variety of hand dishwashing products, body washes, and other consumer goods at the site.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS: P&G president touts L. acquisition's 'great growth potential'
summary: Jennifer Davis, president of Procter & Gamble Co.'s Global Feminine Care division, discussed the "great growth potential" of a recent acquisition. She stated that the acquisition would help P&G appeal to younger consumers. The article is framed as "FIVE QUESTIONS," implying an interview format, though the full questions and answers are not provided in this snippet.

title: P&G buys purpose-driven feminine care marketer This Is L.
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has acquired This Is L., a purpose-driven feminine care products maker known for its L. brand made with organic cotton. The acquisition aligns with P&G's strategy to center its business around purpose and tap into the disruptor market for organic materials in feminine care. This move complements P&G's existing feminine care portfolio and reflects a broader CPG trend of acquiring startup brands.

title: P&G strikes licensing deal for Febreze product
summary: Procter & Gamble has entered into a licensing agreement with Helen of Troy, allowing Helen of Troy to use the Febreze brand name on its OdorGrab Air Cleaner product. This deal enables brand expansion for Febreze into the air purifier market. The agreement was updated on January 30, 2019.

title: Employment approaches 800 at P&G plant; shampoo production underway
summary: Procter & Gamble's new plant in Berkeley County, W.Va., is nearing completion, with exterior construction 90% done and shampoo production already underway. The company currently employs 785 workers and plans to hire an additional 300-plus within the next 18 months. This $500 million investment is part of a North American supply chain transformation, involving the transfer of production from other P&G facilities that are closing or downsizing.

title: Colgate-Palmolive expects profit to decline in 2019
summary: Colgate-Palmolive forecasts a surprise drop in 2019 profit, blaming higher raw material costs and a stronger dollar, impacting its shares. Despite beating revenue estimates with $3.81 billion, the company anticipates a mid-single-digit decline in earnings per share for the year due to increased advertising spending and fluctuating exchange rates. This comes as the company faces stiff competition and challenges in key markets like Latin America, despite strong sales in North America.

title: Colgate predicts lower profits in 2019 as strong dollar bites
summary: Colgate-Palmolive forecasts a decline in 2019 profits due to the strong dollar, which exacerbates emerging market sales issues and rising input costs. The company expects earnings per share to fall by "low-single-digit" levels, contradicting analyst expectations for a rise, and anticipates flat to modestly higher net sales. This outlook led to a 3.2 percent drop in Colgate shares in pre-market trading, as the strong dollar makes products more expensive overseas and diminishes repatriated revenues.

title: P&G releases refillable packaging
summary: Procter & Gamble has partnered with Loop, a circular e-commerce platform by TerraCycle, to introduce refillable packaging and "collect and recycle" solutions for many of its global brands. This initiative aims to eliminate packaging waste and is part of P&G's Ambition 2030 sustainability goals, with initial testing beginning in mid-2019 in New York and Paris. The collaboration focuses on durable, reusable packaging for popular products like Pantene, Tide, Cascade, and Crest, along with circular solutions for hygiene products and grooming items.

title: P&G releases refillable packaging
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) announced a partnership with TerraCycle's Loop platform to introduce "collect and recycle" solutions for its brands, aiming to eliminate packaging waste. As part of this initiative, P&G is also launching reusable, refillable packaging for several of its popular products, to reduce reliance on single-use packaging. The program will be validated through in-market learning experiments in New York and Paris starting mid-2019.

title: Turnaround traction? P&G reports stronger sales - again, stock soars
summary: Procter & Gamble reported another strong quarter of growth, prompting an increase in its annual sales forecast. Organic sales rose 4 percent for the second consecutive quarter, leading to a 4.9 percent increase in stock price. Despite overall positive results, the grooming unit experienced a dip, and the company is facing challenges with raw material costs.

title: What that Gillette ad says about the trend in woke advertising
summary: Procter & Gamble's Gillette released a new ad addressing "toxic masculinity" and the #MeToo movement, following a trend of companies taking stances on social issues. The article explores how this "woke" advertising strategy can be successful, citing examples like Nike's Colin Kaepernick campaign, while also warning about failures like Pepsi's and Ram Trucks' ads that were perceived as artificial. Ultimately, the success of such campaigns hinges on authenticity and consistent follow-through.

title: Dentsu's Carat takes majority of P&G media business
summary: Procter & Gamble has significantly shifted its media business to Dentsu's Carat following a bidding process, though Omnicom's Hearts & Science retains some of the business. P&G is moving more work in-house and providing brands with greater flexibility in media planning and buying while exploring a new media model. The company aims to optimize its media buy and pursue further cost reductions by 2021.

title: I Worked for Gillette's Parent Company for More Than 20 Years. Here's What I Think About Their Crazy Controversial Ad
summary: A former Procter & Gamble marketing executive offers an inside, yet unbiased, perspective on Gillette's controversial "The Best Men Can Be" ad. He argues that while polarizing, the ad successfully evokes emotion and makes a social statement, which he believes is crucial for brand relevance in today's landscape. The author reflects on the ad's impact from both an advertising and social standpoint, concluding that it sparks necessary debate and encourages self-reflection.

title: US based toothpaste firm suffers $11 million loss in Vietnam
summary: Colgate-Palmolive Vietnam is struggling in the competitive oral care market, facing fierce competition from global rivals like Unilever (P/S, Close-up) and local brands. Despite market potential, Colgate's revenue growth has been slow while costs increased, leading to accumulated losses of nearly $11 million by the end of 2017, exceeding its charter capital.

title: Procter & Gamble offshoot brand Opté launches high tech beauty wand
summary: P&G Ventures' offshoot brand Opté has launched the Opté Precision Skincare System, a smart-beauty wand that uses advanced technology to scan, detect, and correct hyperpigmentation. Unveiled at CES 2019, the device combines blue LED scan lights, a digital camera, a Minicomputer Precise Color Algorithm, and a Micro Serum Jet Printer with a Precision Serum. This innovation allows for precise application to only affected areas, offering a new category of digital skincare for Procter & Gamble.

title: We're techy, too! Deere, Tide maker head to CES gadget show
summary: Traditional companies like John Deere and Procter & Gamble are exhibiting at CES for the first time, demonstrating that "every company today is a technology company." They are showcasing innovations ranging from self-driving tractors and AI-powered combine harvesters to smart toothbrushes and heated razors, reflecting a broader economic shift where consumers expect digital experiences. These companies aim to attract investors, partners, and skilled employees by highlighting their tech-forward initiatives.

title: Procter & Gamble Amps Up Beauty Tech at CES
summary: Procter & Gamble showcased its advancements in beauty technology at CES, featuring connected products across its beauty, health, and skincare portfolios. The company unveiled innovations like SK-II's Future X Smart Store, an updated AI-based Olay Skin Advisor, the Opté Precision Skincare System, and the AIRIA smart home fragrance system. P&G also highlighted the Oral-B Genius X toothbrush and a new Heated Razor by GilletteLabs, emphasizing its commitment to combining technology with consumer understanding.

title: Why Global Baby Care Products Market is demanding globally with
summary: The global baby care products market is experiencing significant demand, driven by increasing parental awareness of child safety, rising disposable incomes, and the growth of the working women population. Key players like Procter & Gamble, Kimberly Clark, and Johnson & Johnson are leading this market, which is projected to grow to over $110 billion by 2025 with a CAGR of 6%. North America currently holds the largest share due to high expenditure and progressive technology, though high costs and a lack of regulatory guidelines pose challenges to market growth.

title: Procter & Gamble inks toothpaste licensing deal with Burt’s Bees
summary: Procter & Gamble has signed a licensing deal with Burt's Bees to begin manufacturing Burt's Bees toothpaste products. This move by P&G follows extensive research into consumer demand for natural products, with 35% of U.S. consumers interested in simple and effective toothpaste formulas. While toothpaste is the initial focus, other products may be considered for the future.

title: Monro Inc. Appoints New Chief Information and Marketing Officers
summary: Monro Inc. has appointed Deborah Brundage as senior vice president – chief marketing officer and promoted Avi Dasgupta to senior vice president – chief information officer. Brundage will continue to lead initiatives for customer retention, acquisition, and omnichannel presence, while Dasgupta will oversee the entire IT organization, reporting to President and CEO Brett Ponton. These appointments are part of strengthening Monro's senior leadership and executing its Monro.Forward strategy.

title: A tale of two city factories
summary: This article contrasts the fates of two major manufacturing plants in Augusta: Graphic Packaging Holding Co.'s mill, which is undergoing a $350 million modernization, and Dart Container Corp.'s factory, which is closing by mid-2019 due to weak demand for its polystyrene cups. It also touches on recent layoffs and management changes at Textron Specialized Vehicles and other local business news. The piece highlights the impact these industries have had on the community and its workforce.

title: Building a More Just Marketplace: The 2018 Rankings of America’s Most JUST Companies
summary: This report details JUST Capital's 2018 rankings of America's Most JUST Companies, identifying corporations that excel in areas important to the American public, such as fair pay, environmental impact, and community support. The rankings highlight that JUST 100 companies outperform their peers financially and socially, with Microsoft topping the list. The article emphasizes how these rankings can guide consumers and investors toward businesses driving a more just economy.

title: Textron to lay off 400 workers
summary: Textron Inc. announced it would lay off approximately 400 employees, roughly 10 percent of its workforce, due to "significant changes" since acquiring Arctic Cat in 2017 and "significantly below expectations" operating results from the Arctic Cat and Textron Off Road brands. The downsizing, which includes closing several turf-care branch locations and a manufacturing facility in Indiana (resulting in 107 lost jobs), is estimated to cost up to $85 million. It is unclear how many, if any, of these layoffs will affect Textron Specialized Vehicles' operations in Augusta.

title: The activist who shook up P&G is at it again with a big industrial player
summary: Activist investor Ed Garden of Trian Partners is targeting PPG Industries, advocating for a management change and a company split. Trian, which recently won a board seat at Procter & Gamble, believes current PPG CEO Michael McGarry should be replaced by former chief Chuck Bunch, and the company should divide into an architectural coatings and an industrials company to improve performance. This comes after PPG issued its third consecutive third-quarter profit warning and lost a major business contract with Lowe's.

title: Out of boxes! Colgate-Palmolive suspends operations in Venezuela
summary: Colgate-Palmolive has suspended operations at one of its five factories in Venezuela due to a lack of cardboard for packaging, following the Venezuelan government's expropriation of Smurfit Kappa, the cardboard supplier. This action is part of a larger trend of company closures and production cuts in Venezuela, including Kimberly-Clark and Kellogg's, caused by the country's severe economic crisis and government policies. Mexican bottler Coca-Cola Femsa is also considering significant layoffs and production scale-backs in response to the challenging market conditions.

title: Shampoo Market by Product Type, Business Strategies, Development Factors & Forecast 2025: Unilever, Henkel, Church & Dwight Co., Inc., Kimberly-Clark, Kao Corporation, Beiersdorf, Amway, Shiseido, L'Oréal, Adelco SA, Clarion Cosmetics
summary: The global shampoo market is projected to reach USD 35986.8 million by 2025, growing at a CAGR of 4.1% from USD 28277.4 million in 2017, driven by increasing user demand, changing lifestyles, and product innovations. Key market players like Unilever, Henkel, and P&G are employing strategies such as new product launches and acquisitions to expand their market footprint. The market is segmented by product type, price, demographics, and distribution channels, with rising hair-related disorders and urbanization identified as key drivers, while counterfeit products and trade barriers pose significant restraints.

title: Third Point Seeks to Oust Campbell Soup’s Board (Published 2018)
summary: Third Point, an investment firm led by Daniel S. Loeb, is attempting to replace the entire board of the Campbell Soup Company by nominating 12 candidates. This aggressive move comes as Campbell Soup has faced stagnant sales and declining popularity of its main products. The bid aims to pressure the company into a sale, with one of the nominees being a scion of Campbell's controlling family who has been critical of the company's current direction.

title: Dish Soap Market SWOT Analysis by Key Players Procter & Gamble, Colgate-Palmolive Company, Unilever
summary: HTF Market Intelligence Consulting Pvt. Ltd. has released a new market study on the 2012-2023 Global Dish Soap Market, providing a comprehensive assessment with future trends, growth factors, and industry-validated data. The report forecasts the market until 2025 and includes a SWOT analysis of key players such as Procter & Gamble, Colgate-Palmolive Company, and Unilever. It also covers geographical analysis, competitive landscape, and company profiles, aiming to help clients identify growth opportunities and strategic planning.

title: Estee Lauder | $EL Stock | Shares Rise On Q4 Revenue Jump
summary: Estee Lauder (NYSE: EL) shares rose after the company reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and revenue, driven by strong sales in La Mer Skincare and Clinique products. Despite the positive Q4 results, the company issued weaker-than-expected guidance for the first quarter and full fiscal year 2019. CEO Fabrizio Freda highlighted a strong fiscal 2018 with growth across all regions and product categories, expressing confidence in continued industry-leading sales and double-digit EPS growth for fiscal 2019.

title: What Food Science Can Lend to Skin Care
summary: This article explores the growing convergence between the food and personal care industries, particularly how food science principles, sensory research, and clean label trends are influencing skin care product development. It highlights how consumer demand for natural ingredients and ethical sourcing is driving this shift, and how sensory evaluation techniques used for food can be adapted to optimize the texture and feel of skin care products.

title: Kraft Heinz to make all packaging recyclable by 2025
summary: Kraft Heinz announced a commitment to make 100 percent of its global packaging recyclable, reusable, or compostable by 2025. This initiative will involve partnering with experts to develop alternative materials, potentially leading to significant changes for iconic products like Heinz ketchup packets and Kraft Singles packaging. The company faces challenges in finding sustainable solutions that also meet food safety and cost requirements, but is committed to innovating in this "brand-new territory."

title: This Week’s Exec Shifts: Allstate, Priceline, MedMen Appoint CMOs
summary: This article details executive leadership changes across various companies, with a focus on Chief Marketing Officer appointments. Key moves include Elizabeth Brady joining Allstate as EVP and chief marketing, innovation, and corporate relations officer, Ben Harrell being promoted to CMO at Priceline, and David H. Dancer becoming CMO for cannabis retailer MedMen. The report also covers marketing leadership changes at Domino's, Scooter's Coffee, PetSmart Charities, PepsiCo, Hilton, and several other brands.

title: What’s the Dividend Yield of the Consumer Non-Cyclical Sector?
summary: The consumer non-cyclical sector recorded an average dividend yield of 3%, with the tobacco segment noting the highest yield at 5.3%. Various industries within this sector, including brewers, personal products, and food processing, have outperformed broad-based indexes in dividend yields. The article also highlights ETFs with exposure to consumer non-cyclical sectors, such as the WisdomTree US SmallCap Dividend ETF and the iShares Core High Dividend ETF.

title: Whittington to take over as La-Z-Boy CFO
summary: Melinda D. Whittington has been appointed as the new senior vice president and chief financial officer for La-Z-Boy Incorporated, starting June 21, succeeding Louis M. “Mike” Riccio. Whittington brings over 25 years of financial experience from companies like Allscripts Healthcare Solutions, Kraft Foods Group Inc., and Procter & Gamble Co. She will lead a global finance team and oversee various financial responsibilities, with leadership expressing enthusiasm for her skills and experience in the consumer products arena.

title: Kraft Heinz UK CMO on bringing ‘the magic’ back to marketing
summary: Steve Chantry, UK and Ireland commercial director and CMO of Kraft Heinz, discusses his efforts to shift the company's image from ruthlessly cost-driven to one focused on effectiveness and culture. He details the company's journey back to growth, increased marketing spend, and new approaches to innovation, sustainability, and marketing effectiveness, including a focus on blending "magic and logic" and investing in talent development. Chantry also emphasizes the growing importance of e-commerce and fostering collaboration with retail partners.

title: Taco Bell's CEO jumps ship to head Chipotle
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill announced Brian Niccol, current CEO of Taco Bell, will take over as its new CEO starting March 5th, replacing founder Steve Ells. Niccol's appointment comes as Chipotle aims to recover from food-safety issues and criticism over its queso. Wall Street reacted positively to the news, with Chipotle's stock rising significantly in after-hours trading, reflecting optimism for Niccol's experience in turning around Taco Bell.

title: Kimberly-Clark: Segment Performances in 4Q17
summary: Kimberly-Clark's Personal Care segment returned to growth in 4Q17, with sales increasing 1.2% driven by improved volumes and a favorable product mix. The Consumer Tissue segment saw a slight decline in sales, while the Kimberly-Clark Professional segment continued to grow with a 3.1% rise. Regional performance varied, with North America facing challenges due to promotional spending, while developing and emerging markets showed stronger growth.

title: Kimberly-Clark to cut 5,000 jobs on sluggish sales partly due to fewer babies
summary: Kimberly-Clark plans to cut 5,000 to 5,500 jobs, representing 12% to 13% of its workforce, and slash costs by $1.5 billion over the next four years due to sluggish sales. The company attributes this decline partly to lower birthrates in key markets like the U.S. and South Korea, impacting demand for products like Huggies. Despite a 22% increase in profit, sales rose only 1%, prompting a major restructuring to improve competitiveness and profitability.

title: Price War Pressures Consumer-Goods Giants
summary: A price war in the consumer goods market is squeezing profits for major companies like Procter & Gamble and Kimberly-Clark. P&G reported its first average price decline since 2011 due to widespread discounting to boost sales, while Kimberly-Clark plans job cuts. These companies are now focusing on higher-end products and new offerings to combat price pressure.

title: American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault will become Facebook’s first black board member
summary: Facebook announced that Kenneth Chenault, the departing CEO of American Express, will join its board of directors, making him the company's first black board member. This move follows criticisms regarding Facebook's lack of diversity on its board and a promise by COO Sheryl Sandberg to appoint an African-American director. Mark Zuckerberg cited Chenault's expertise in customer service, direct commerce, and brand building as key reasons for his recruitment.

title: Edgewell Personal Care to acquire luxury grooming brand Jack Black
summary: Edgewell Personal Care has acquired luxury grooming brand Jack Black, marking its entry into the prestige grooming sector. This acquisition adds Jack Black, known as the best-selling men's prestige skin care brand in the US, to Edgewell's portfolio which includes Schick and Wilkinson Sword. The move is expected to expand Edgewell's personal care portfolio and help it compete in the growing market against rivals like Unilever's Dollar Shave Club and P&G's Gillette on Demand.

title: Kenneth I. Chenault Joins Facebook Board of Directors
summary: Kenneth I. Chenault, CEO of American Express, has been appointed to Facebook's board of directors, effective February 5, 2018. Mark Zuckerberg highlighted Chenault's expertise in customer service, direct commerce, brand building, and social mission. Chenault expressed his enthusiasm to contribute to Facebook's mission of connecting people.

title: How Safe Is Procter & Gamble's (PG) Dividend?
summary: This article analyzes the safety and growth prospects of Procter & Gamble's (PG) dividend, highlighting its 61-year streak of increases. It examines P&G's payout ratio, considering the impact of asset divestments, and discusses recent operating trends and sales growth. The author concludes that while P&G offers consistent, steady dividend growth, aggressive income investors may seek faster-growing alternatives.

title: Better Buy: Procter & Gamble Company vs. Philip Morris International
summary: This article compares Procter & Gamble (PG) and Philip Morris International (PM) as dividend investment choices. It evaluates their financial fortitude, growth prospects, and valuation, concluding that while P&G has greater financial strength, Philip Morris shows stronger future growth potential. The decision ultimately depends on investor preferences regarding balance sheet strength versus growth and comfort with "sin stocks."
